Replies.Author: yusuftemel
Replies.Body: To achieve the 'Galaxy Brain' achievement, take note of the following: Answer at least 2 discussions. Take note, you CANNOT mark your own answers to your own questions. They have to be marked by another user. Discussions should be in a public repository. There's a current bug observed by some users whereby marking your own answers can prevent you from getting the badge instead. Hope this answer has helped you, and all the best in getting the achievement! :)

Title: feed back on achievement badges
Author: SteveALee
Body: Please turn these off by default. Gamification has no place here. Useless twaddle.

Answers.Author: jgmac1106
Answers.Body: i agree on off by default. Always default to privacy. I disagree on utility. If the achievements had useful metadata that complied with current industry recommendations the information could be ingested to track role based training requirements of developers, aid in portfolio reviews, and allow users to control their learning data outside of employers. Granted the achievements (little disappointing) are just images for now, but it could be easily extendable to allow parsing, ignestiong, and recording in an immutable ledger.

Replies.Author: SteveALee
Replies.Body: That's an interesting idea but a big "if" to get the badges representing meaningful development metrics rather than feel good.

Replies.Author: seek-dev
Replies.Body: Gamifying something just to sell more metadata to corporations who parasitize human privacy is inherently exploitation. The purpose is to manifest addictive behaviour with immaterial rewards. Which is a manipulative function of industrial psychology, though common practice in today's ecosystems of consumer spyware and vacuous social media.

Answers.Author: MrSarno
Answers.Body: I'm not sure whether you're aware, but there is a setting to disable them here. I don't feel strongly about your suggestion one way or the other. I think people are more likely to check for settings to disable features they dislike than they are to search for features they might hypothetially like and wish to enable. In addition, some people may not think to look for settings, and so there would likely be a significant number of people reporting the lack of achievements as a bug, and / or creating discussions to ask why they don't appear to be working. At least the setting's there for those who want it.

Replies.Author: MlgmXyysd
Replies.Body: I agree with this point

Replies.Author: mark-i-m
Replies.Body: Thanks for this! I would never have found that setting on my own.

Answers.Author: johnno1962
Answers.Body: Can we cut it out with these new "achievement" badges already? I am now being shamed for "closing a PR within 5 minutes of opening it" and "merging a PR to my own repo without a review". This is all just puerile. Make it opt-in and grow up.

Answers.Author: return42
Answers.Body: Remove this "feel good" crap.

Answers.Author: suchov
Answers.Body: I love them! ❤️

Replies.Author: johnno1962
Replies.Body: Was it really necessary to put a "YOLO" badge against my account because I didn't wait out a reviewer? What it is supposed to say about me? What purpose does saying that serve? According to google: "YOLO" is an acronym for "you only live once". Along the same lines as the Latin carpe diem, it is a call to live life to its fullest extent, even embracing behavior which carries inherent risk. It became a popular internet slang term in 2012.

Replies.Author: suchov
Replies.Body: Repo with many stars, many PR's merged - can be a stimulus to newbies ...

Replies.Author: return42
Replies.Body: When "many" means a value of 10 or 15? It feels like kindergarten, where everyone gets a pink unicorn badge. Everyone is happy and the parents of each child are proud.

Replies.Author: suchov
Replies.Body: So your suggestion is to higher the bar to get the badge?

Replies.Author: return42
Replies.Body: IMO all badges lack sustainable information. The one you mentioned ".. can be a stimulus to newbies .." might be reasonable .. but what ever limit gh sets .. the users will find a way to increase their ratings / like mentioned here or here .. I already have seen bots faking the activity on gh ..

Answers.Author: piazzai
Answers.Body: I completely agree. Unfortunately the chances that they roll back a feature that was already deployed in beta are very low. This should have been stopped at an earlier stage of the development process. Though the amount of users out there who are currently trading stars, answering each other's bogus discussions, coordinating to get the pair achievement, etc., should be a strong indication for product managers that they really didn't think this one through.

Answers.Author: ilechuks73
Answers.Body: I love it, now there's colors, lots of colors on my github profile. the only issue that may arise from this is having a cluttered UI if more features like this are getting rolled out. The senior and veteran software engineer might not need this but for the entry level developers like me whose portfolio is their github profile, it helps spice things up.

Answers.Author: ghost
Answers.Body: I hope also they don't add more, because it will rush a lot of people doing trivial things or doing nothing to get one. Proof of this is a large number of empty discussions to get an achievement But I do not deny that these achievements have pushed me forward, to make a lot of contribution

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: as always, there are opposing views here but the most important thing is it can be hidden at the Settings, a user can even set his / her profile to private, so no gamification at all

Answers.Author: sfertman
Answers.Body: Agree, this is such a useless waste of time. git is for code sharing and colab. Stop trying to make github into facebook/twitter. It's a distraction and will never work.

Answers.Author: johnno1962
Answers.Body: This is the sort of b.s. badges incentivise: johnno1962/injectionforxcode#303 and repo owners have to put up with. This frivolity doesn't come at zero cost.

Answers.Author: seek-dev
Answers.Body: This kind of 'gamification' is purposefully designed to exploit addictive behaviour with immaterial social media internet points. There's no denying the psychological impact these 'banana stickers' are intended to have. They are intended to reward and/or punish people within the scope of social media, which git is not supposed to be. By getting people addicted to chasing meaningless -- and even harmful -- activity, you're getting people addicted to the platform itself. That is, of course, the real intent: Capitalist monopolization through psychological exploitation and (esp in the case of Microsoft) owning every damn thing, software, idea, concept, material work, organization, means of communication, collaborative space, etc. there is. The secondary purpose here is creating and visually quantifying user metadata, which is being gathered on users (inherently anti-privacy) and sold as a product. The concept of open-source was never to monopolize, spy on, or manipulate people. How did our tools for collectivism, cooperation and public good, merely become an opportunity for billionaire plutocrats to turn human privacy into just another thing to sell? Surveillance capitalism, that's how.

Title: Pull Shark not updating

Body: Hi, I have completed over 300 pull requests in a private repository from my work account but the badges are not updating on my profile. Title: Make the old badges look like the new ones
Author: ovflowd
Body: Right now, the Arctic Code Vault, Mars Satellite and Public Sponsor Badges don't fit the new rounded design, which is quite strange and feels a bit discerning UX-wise as they're different from the others. I honestly believe it would make sense to align them and make them look like the others, if not.

Title: Magic carpet ride badge for full year of consecutive commits
Author: przemekpi
Body: Hi, I'm not sure it this is the right place for it, but I thought about the idea of new badge for full year of consecutive commits: Magic carpet ride Reasoning: Full year of commits is quite an achievement and kind of looks like a knitted carpet with different hues of threads on people profile (apart also from looking like bathroom tiles). Also the song is cool. If there is another place that this proposal suits better I'd be glad if you let me know :) Or maybe I've missed something and there is a proposal like that? Thanks!

Answers.Author: 0dminnimda
Answers.Body: People can use some special tools to mangle with their previous commits to achieve this, and it's not so difficult to do I would prefer not to encourage this behavior by adding such an achievement

Title: Galaxy brain badge achievement bug
Author: rickstaa
Body: I think a bug in the Galaxy Brain achievement badge prevents it from being shown. I checked my answered discussions (see https://github.com/search?p=1&q=commenter%3Arickstaa&type=Discussions ), and I have 23 answered discussions while I only received the 2x galaxy brain badge (see https://github.com/rickstaa?achievement=galaxy-brain&tab=achievements ). Answered discussions Follow the Youtube tutorial but the deploy is failed anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1931 PR count should not be 0 anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1932 How to run this project locally so that i can try and contribute different themes? anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1930 Top Languages card not showing any data anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1878 Translucent/transparent card themes anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1920 TOP LANGs does count languages in repos I contributed to? anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1916 Top languages card is empty anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1910 How to count repositories in Organizations anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1914 Pull request: Varcel authorisation anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1898 Dynamic theme based on viewer's github theme? anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1880 border_color not working anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1865 Theme not working for top langauge card anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1847 Stats not correct? anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1797 (NOT FIRST MARKED ANSWER) Empty top languages anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1790 How to change bg color to gradient 🌈 anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1742 Is there a way to hide a repo from contributing to the top languages stats? anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1738 Do the top languages stats support private repositories? anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1716 How do the PR stats work? anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1686 How to set up a repo card? anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1682 Hide languages anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1683 Rank Only Stats Card anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#719 Will this work with Orgs anuraghazra/github-readme-stats#1565 I checked, and I have no self-selected answers.

Answers.Author: melvincwng
Answers.Body: @rickstaa, try submitting a ticket to GitHub Bug Report over here. Provide them a couple of working days to investigate the issue. Personally, I do notice this issue as well in some of the other users in this discussion forum, who contributed alot in answering questions as well. Hope this helps.

Replies.Author: rickstaa
Replies.Body: @melvincwng Great, I just did that. Thanks for your answer.

Title: I think we should have a badge for Code review
Author: ptmy-it
Body: I really love the badges and achievements system of GitHub. However, I think it is missing a badge for the Code review for this is also an essential activity on GitHub. To be honest, I've learned a lot from code reviewing others' code and being code reviewed by others. Since we are having the badge for the Pull Request . And well... the PRs should be reviewed and approved before merging. So I think it's fair to have one for the Code review as well. That makes sense, right?

Answers.Author: alexwholland
Answers.Body: Better then having the YOLO badge that awards merges without review.

Answers.Author: unixorn
Answers.Body: In my opinion, having someone else look at PRs is part of what makes Open Source so powerful.

Answers.Author: Trilochna
Answers.Body: Yes i agree with you. I also feel that GitHub should provide more achievements and badges it is really fascinating and motivates to work.

Title: Repository-specific badges
Author: cconard96
Body: It could be nice to have the ability for repository maintainers to grant badges to their contributors. As an example, they could be to reward users who add their own tests for code they contribute or other actions that are specific to their code or issues. Rather then let repositories create custom awards, they could be created by GitHub and just awarded by individual project maintainers. These badges could show up under a "Project badges" section/page instead of directly on the profile.

Answers.Author: OOCAZ
Answers.Body: I don't know that there is a simple answer for this question. Some people like them, others don't. I think the option to mute or hide achievements and achievement notifications we can meet a happy middle ground. Sure they "game-ify" PR's to an extent. But the people who just want the badge will get it and move on with their life. No different than any one who just wanted to say they contributed to an open source project just to say they did. I think GitHub is very open for feedback on the different achievements and a few revisions to the achievements could help those looking to "game-ify" the experience a bigger contributor. But in the end it's just a cool thing to keep some people engaged.

Title: Achievement bug
Author: Turtlebole
Body: I noticed that I unlocked 3 of the beta achievements, but only 2 of them are displaying on my profile, while when the Achievement field is clicked it shows that I have 3 of them. I am unsure if this is a bug, did anyone else experience similar things?

Answers.Author: melvincwng
Answers.Body: Hi @Turtlebole, based on what I've seen from your profile, I have two suggestions - please feel free to try out either one:   I noticed the 'QuickDraw' achievement is missing. This could be because in your PR over here, it could be because the PR was closed and not merged. Try merging another PR within 5 mins instead of closing it, and see if the achievement reappears.   If that doesn't work, it could be a bug. In that case, you would have to raise a ticket to GitHub Bug Report. Explain to them the situation, and provide them at least a few working days to investigate and resolve the issue.   Hope this answers your question, take care 😄

Replies.Author: Turtlebole
Replies.Body: Thank you for the options, tried merging another PR within 5 minutes but it didn't work, maybe I did something wrong, I am actually unsure 😅, it could be a visual bug.

Replies.Author: melvincwng
Replies.Body: @Turtlebole, in that case, I would highly suggest you submit a ticket to GitHub Bug Report - https://support.github.com/contact/bug-report They usually respond pretty quickly, and if it's really an issue on their end, I'm sure you'll get your badge very soon :) Take care, and good luck!

Title: Pair Extraordinaire achievement from private organisation repository
Author: twistezo
Body: We are working inside private GitHub organisation on private repository. We have a lot of coauthored commits on default branch but none of them are counted on our public profiles. Usually we create Pull Request. Each one adds some commits. One of us in GitHub web interface click Squash and merge (to default branch) and GH adds to commit message info about authors. Example of our commit from git log : commit 123... Author: Foo Bar <foobar@gmail.com> Date: Wed Aug 31 12:56:36 2022 +0200 Some msg Co-authored-by: Foo Baz <foobaz@gmail.com> where both e-mails are connected to public GH accounts. Where is the problem? Private org, private repo or maybe in commit message? PS. I have Include Private contributions on my profile checked in my GH options.

Answers.Author: airtower-luna
Answers.Body: From my experience the co-authored commit must exist in a PR before merging, and you get the achievement when that PR gets merged.

Answers.Author: F4NT0
Answers.Body: Try in a public repo, put your colleage as a Collaborator and he needs to accept on the email, create a new branch, change something and make the commit on the github web putting like the image below the co-author message and create a PR, put you college as a reviewer and merge the PR without the review, it works for me for the YOLO badge and the Pair Extraordinaire.

Answers.Author: Anmol-Baranwal
Answers.Body: You can check my profile here & you can see that my co-authored commit was counted in a private repository, of which I deleted and the link became inaccessible. So, yes you can get it even in a private repository but you must make a PR from a different branch, and you can just make one co-authored commit for the PR changes which will do just fine.

Title: Style and content of new achievement badges trivialise actual achievements
Author: thclark
Body: It was REALLY AWESOME to be made an arctic code vault contributor. Having that shield there under achievements on my profile was really a point of pride. Recently, new achievements have been introduced, and I have a HUGE problem with both content and styling. Styling Remember, people's GitHub profiles form their CVs - they need to convey professionalism. Mine is linked to from LinkedIn, and lots of other places - it's the first place people go to if they need to assess whether they're any good, but it currently looks like Candy Crush Saga. These weird cartoon emoji are massive, and distract the eye from actual content, and hugely trivialise my profile. Content Achievement badges should represent an achievement. It should be possible to see someone's achievement badges and make some assessment of where they are as a contributor and developer. Forced upon my profile I now have: "YOLO" which tells people that I merged a PR without a review, generally a bad practice but not really optional if you're the sole maintainer. "QUICKDRAW" which tells people that I opened an issue then closed it. On day 1 of using GitHub, probably. "PULL SHARK" which tells people that I made a pull request. Literally the most basic aspect of working with git. I acknowledge the need to have achievement badges to encourage beginners, but many fragmented ones diminish those that are meaningful... none of the above are appropriate for a 15-year career developer who spends an average of 3 hours a day on GitHub. A simpler system might be appropriate - "Getting Started" could be replaced with "Moving up", then with "Git Hero" etc, and we'll know where people are at a glance without that panel getting so busy it's meaningless. That would also be actually helpful, because in reviewing developer's CVs (i.e. their GitHub profiles!) it's nice to be able to see at a glance what level they're at with git, especially when hiring at a junior level. There's a new STARSTRUCK one, which is fairly nice as it marks that some of your repos are getting traction in the OSS community, but the styling is still trivialising it, sadly. Suggested course of action It would be good to keep achievements on my profile, rather than have to remove them entirely, because they have the potential to be (and indeed were) a great way of motivating myself and displaying credibility to the world. For this not to be lost: Make sure they're actual achievements, hard-won and meaningful and/or Enable me to curate which ones are shown so my profile still looks professional and I can decide which are meaningful.

Answers.Author: heymage
Answers.Body: Hi @thclark, if you don't like the Achievements on your public profile, you can disable them in your settings at Public Profile > Profile settings. Hope that helps

Replies.Author: thclark
Replies.Body: Hi @heymage thank you, I'm aware... but I had an actual achievement and want it to be there, as I was proud of it. I've re-titled and edited my feedback above, partly to suppress the fact that I was pretty angry about this (which isn't helpful in feedback) and partly to clarify this aspect.

Replies.Author: heymage
Replies.Body: I see, maybe it would be possible to explicitly mark which achievements to show and which not on the public profile to gain power about that.

Replies.Author: thclark
Replies.Body: That would solve half the problem (i.e. enable us to restrict our own profile to useful information only). The other half of the problem is the the noise affecting the usefulness GitHub, eg whilst browsing other people's profiles. When hiring devs, for example, the first thing to do is look at someone's GitHub profile to tell whether this is someone mature and established or whether they're raw and junior. Having meaningful achievements supports that, having a load of not-at-all-meaningful achievements prohibits it. If you'd like some evidence that they're not very meaningful, you can check out this other discussion, full of people trying to get a YOLO badge by creating new repositories and fiddling with pull requests for no actual reason. Gamifying GitHub to incentivise good practice might not be a bad philosophy (above the scope of this discussion), but gamifying it to encourage bad practices and additional noise and clutter is surely a very bad plan. There's the opportunity with Achievements to do something really credible and powerful for people's GitHub profiles, and I feel like this opportunity is being squandered.

Replies.Author: heymage
Replies.Body: I'm totally with you on this.

Replies.Body: mark my reply i want get badge

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: yup, one valid request here is to select only the badges to be displayed, as of now, it's all or nothing as for being not too professional looking or other says "cartoonish" and "childish", well, we need to balance all of the users of GitHub, others are actually very proud of it, as we will differ on our opinion and view

Answers.Author: whithajess
Answers.Body: I felt the exact same as @thclark was proud of my arctic code vault contributor badge and then felt patronised by the new badges - totally understand balancing all users of Github, this particular feature at the moment is not balanced. I would suggest that if someone has made 100s or 1000s of PRs that QUICKDRAW or PULL SHARK should not show on their badges. YOLO I am not even sure should exist but maybe thats personal opinion.

Answers.Author: thenithinbalaji
Answers.Body: Yeah true.  Achievements should be displayed in a separate tab and not under the profile. It should be fully transparent, and stuff like PRs and discussions made in private repos should not count for the process. If someone chose to turn achievements off, then, Github should display the "the user has turned off achievements" message since a few people already believe that more badges = more superior. Ability to report and remove someone's badge permanently if it's not authentic. Will prevent people from asking others to star their repo or mark theirs as answers in discussions. Except for Pull Shark and Starstruck badges, the other badges do not support or promote people to contribute to open-source in any way. They must be removed. Ability to turn off certain badges rather than turning off the entire set of achievements.  If you have any other suggestions, additions, or deletions, add them in the comments here #28686 (comment). Let's make Github hear!

Title: How to learn programming？
Author: cxman1
Body: Programming is really brain burning. It's hard to make achievements I need the help of experts 😵 😶‍🌫️ 😵

Answers.Author: HadrienBoyer
Answers.Body: You should start to read and check on websites that gives you tutorials, read code and practice! There is a lot of way to start, you can read a book for the start and to learn the basics, and then start the tutorials/exercices that are largely available on the web, including YouTube (I like YouTube's tutorials because it's free and the "teacher" usually know his topic and explain each line of code). Have a nice journey into development! :)

Replies.Author: cxman1
Replies.Body: Thank you for your answer. Thank you very much

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: and it's really frustrating most of the time, even if you are already a software developer, if you watch even, say, some Tech Leads in top-tech companies, they are saying that you will feel you are not progressing too, and you can't feel your work is done, that's the nature of being a developer, that's why, other IT companies are applying the Agile way, so at least, the team can feel a progress that's same thing when I was hired as a developer, I never had this feeling for 8 years as a teacher, and this was me when I was hired, during the times when I was learning programming, that was so frustrating even if, say, you already learned one programming language then you go to next, particularly, say, from a BASIC language to an OOP, they are really very different when it comes to syntax, and say, from a language to a framework, that will be always a daunting task as if you don't know anything so how did I progress ? first, I had the interest of programming computer, the concept of programmable computer, that you can program, say, a business problem solution or 3D games, I'd never known that in my childhood, that computer games were actually being programmed, in my mind, that's the computer that created these games automatically, so you need to write programs, even small ones, out of your interest, just pick one language, I started in PureBasic, you can pick Python you just need to learn the core, that's actually very important, most of your coding problems will revolve around that: variables, data types, arrays, conditionals, loops etc., here is my own list https://github.com/jdevstatic/programming-core-concepts and as you progress, there will be interesting problems that you will be needing to solve, for example, I never really had the interest of learning JavaScript, but when I was creating my static site, I really need to use it and CSS, so, as I progressed I'm learning that at the same time, take note, even in real-world programming, you need to keep that habit of learning, it's always happening

Replies.Author: cxman1
Replies.Body: In the process of learning, many knowledge points are too detailed and tedious. After learning new knowledge for a period of time, I will always forget some details of knowledge. The chain reaction of programming leads to the collapse of the whole program. I need to settle down well.

Replies.Author: jdevstatic
Replies.Body: just small programs will do, along the way, you will learn how to decouple components, in such a way that when you add or change one functionality, side effects should be minimum but again, it's in real scenario, just practice grouping task into functions at first, make sure it only do one task and if it's becoming too long, you might want to break it to several functions too, variables that are general in scope should be at least at minimum speaking of forgetting details, yup, I can't even write code without documentation, it's always necessary, you don't need to memorize all of the syntax

Title: [Achievement Request]: Issue Muncher
Author: mdanish-kh
Body: Can't think of a better name, but I'll leave the creative naming to the community. Proposal https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue As GitHub has support for closing an issue through a linked PR, a useful achievement would be to keep track of how many issues one has helped to close through linked PRs. The credit for closing the issue for this achievement should be given to the author of the PR not the one who merges it. (I say this because the current behavior is that the issue is closed with the message: <Merger_name> closed this issue in <PR#> ). I believe this would be a better achievement that adds value to a person's profile and acknowledges one's contributions more appropriately than other achievements.

Answers.Author: ArnabDey1543
Answers.Body: Can't think of a better name, but I'll leave the creative naming to the community. Proposal https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue As GitHub has support for closing an issue through a linked PR, a useful achievement would be to keep track of how many issues one has helped to close through linked PRs. I believe this would be a better achievement that adds value to a person's profile and acknowledges one's contributions more appropriately than other achievements.  Link Tracker

Body: https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements

Answers.Author: developersung13
Answers.Body: you need to create co-authored commits on the command line(in a terminal way). e.g.  One thing to note is that the closing quotation mark(") must be written after the co-author's email, and the email must be enclosed in <> (more details ) https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-your-project/creating-and-editing-commits/creating-a-commit-with-multiple-authors

Replies.Author: HwangTaehyun
Replies.Body: Thanks!

Replies.Author: ayyzenn
Replies.Body: In name should we type the actual name of the person or the username? Plus how to use no-reply for email to protect?

Replies.Author: dvdgitman
Replies.Body: If a person chooses to keep their email address private, you should use their GitHub-provided no-reply email to protect their privacy. Otherwise, the co-author's email will be available to the public in the commit message. If you want to keep your email private, you can choose to use a GitHub-provided no-reply email for Git operations and ask other co-authors to list your no-reply email in commit trailers. and FYI I think you need also to merge after the commit., and yes you use the username in name

Title: Star for star is getting out of hand
Author: sid77x
Body: After the addition of the new "Starstruck" achievement badge in github, people have started to ask for star for star where you basically star their reps and they star yours, thus stars have lost all their meaning. It makes getting stars easy and its not about the merit or the quality of the repo anymore. I don't want to be THAT guy but honestly i hope github does something about this

Answers.Author: MrSarno
Answers.Body: Eh. While it does devalue the badge somewhat, I don't think GitHub want to get into the weeds of deciding when one has truly been earned, and when it hasn't. Should someone have their Galaxy Brain badge revoked / down-leveled if there is a consensus that one or more of the discussions they answered was asking a pretty obvious question? The slope can be kind of slippery. Personally, I view badges as callouts that bring your attention to things you can then track down yourself. If someone had the Starstruck badge I would be inclined to look through their repositories to see which had been starred so much and what it was about. If it was clear that so many people were unlikely to hold a genuine interest in such a repo, that would contribute to my opinion of that person. I guess the tl;dr is that, in the eyes of anyone doing their homework, that effectively becomes a badge of shame.

Answers.Author: linuxlawson
Answers.Body: I heard something somewhere once, something like: "when you cheat, you're only cheating yourself". I think it was Yoda.

Replies.Author: sid77x
Replies.Body: true lol

Answers.Body: You can improve your profile by perfecting and publishing all your personal/professional projects/README. Another way is to get Badges to make your profile more attractive, here I teach you how to get an easy achievement: How you can get the Public Sponsor Badge #19916

Answers.Body: Describe yourself.What you do.Which languages youre perfect in and include your projects.Create README.md for repositiries.Describe the repository inside the README.In my perspective that stands out.

Replies.Author: diva-21
Replies.Body: thank you @4ouR04 , kind of you

Answers.Author: tinniaru3005
Answers.Body: Have a good and personalized README.md   GitHub docs for personalized README Eddie Jaoude course   Commits   Commit small changes Good commit messages describing what the commit is for Commit related changes together Commit often Don't Commit Half-Done Work Use Branches   Code   Good README.md is a must The code must not contain duplicate and/or copied lines Write clean, commented, and well-organized code create functions that make your code more structured   Collaboration   Allow others to contribute to your project Raise an issue describing the changes you want Allow others to send a PR solving the issue   Community   Contribute to open-source communities Get involved in discussions Join the chat groups of the communities Try solving the issues on the repositories with the label good-first-issue Participate in open-source programs   PRs   Have patience: The review often takes longer Have your work broken down into small commits. Make the work of the reviewer easy When creating a pull request you should care about the title and the description as a way to provide an overview of why the work is taking place with any relevant links. Do not make assumptions, ask for clarification.   Reviewing PRs   It is a great way to contribute to any project Use emojis to clarify tone. Compare “Looks good :)” or “Looks good! 👍 ” with “It’s fine.” Offer ways to simplify or improve code Do not change the code while reviewing   Join organizations Badges   Achievement Badges

Title: My YOLO and Pull Shark achievements on my profile are wrong and I would like it to be removed

Body: The PRs that are mentioned explaining both badges YOLO and Pull Shark clearly shows that I did not merge the PR without the approval and the PR was not created for a merged branch. These badges are incorrect and technically portrays wrong information on my profile. Please help and remove these badges. Thanks!

Answers.Author: linuxlawson
Answers.Body: You can disable them in your settings if that would help. Some of them are kinda buggy it seems.

Replies.Author: arakshit-tibco
Replies.Body: thanks @linuxlawson for responding. I would not want to disable all badges on my profile but just those buggy ones. @github-staff should fix the logic of how they evaluate these incorrect badges. Thanks!

Replies.Author: arakshit-tibco
Replies.Body: will keep this question unanswered until this has a proper fix. Considering we dont have a concrete answer for this, hope you wont mind @linuxlawson

Replies.Author: linuxlawson
Replies.Body: Nope, I dont mind at all. Here is more info on the achievement badges if you want to take a look at it. Achievement-Badges

Answers.Author: queenofcorgis
Answers.Body: Hi there! The best place to go for answers to account-specific questions like this one is by opening a ticket on our Support page. Please open a ticket with them :)

Answers.Author: airtower-luna
Answers.Body: the PR was not created for a merged branch.  I think you misunderstand the description of the "Pull Shark". It means you have created PRs that have then been merged. Which is usually the goal when creating a PR. 🙂

Answers.Author: NikhilMath
Answers.Body: So your badges are actually correct and are displaying as they're indended to be. You are slightly confused on what they are, but they are right. trust me. I had the same mistake.

Title: Profile badges are patronising, ugly and might be used as a signal of superiority
Author: pond
Body: We're developers, not children; the badges are childish and give very bad impressions in some cases (e.g. the ridiculous "YOLO" for merging a PR without review - what, we're supposed to waste time having humans review PRs from Dependabot which are CI-green, are we?!) or risks being a driver for ivory tower superiority and community tribalism, which is something the developer community already struggles with (I'm not listening to your feature request because I have badges and you don't). If we're going to do these things, can they at least (A) make sense and (B) not look like they're aimed at 5 year olds? It's just embarrassing to have these on my profile. I'd happily have them all gone, forever. Style and content of new achievement badges trivialise actual achievements #28161 Can i get rid of theses badges? #28255 I am not alone. EDIT - I do belatedly note that Profile Settings -> Turn Off Achievements down at the bottom at least lets me turn them all off, which is useful. So long as any of this unprofessional kiddie stuff is in there (I mean, "Gitty Up" - for real?!) then that's certainly how I'll leave things.

Answers.Author: MythodeaLoL
Answers.Body: I also think an option to disable this would be nice.

Replies.Author: linuxlawson
Replies.Body: There is an option to disable, its in your settings. 👍🏼

Answers.Author: Azayzel
Answers.Body: We're developers, not children; the badges are childish and give very bad impressions in some cases (e.g. the ridiculous "YOLO" for merging a PR without review - what, we're supposed to waste time having humans review PRs from Dependabot which are CI-green, are we?!) or risks being a driver for ivory tower superiority and community tribalism, which is something the developer community already struggles with (I'm not listening to your feature request because I have badges and you don't). If we're going to do these things, can they at least (A) make sense and (B) not look like they're aimed at 5 year olds? It's just embarrassing to have these on my profile. I'd happily have them all gone, forever.  Style and content of new achievement badges trivialise actual achievements #28161 Can i get rid of theses badges? #28255  I am not alone. EDIT - I do belatedly note that Profile Settings -> Turn Off Achievements down at the bottom at least lets me turn them all off, which is useful. So long as any of this unprofessional kiddie stuff is in there (I mean, "Gitty Up" - for real?!) then that's certainly how I'll leave things.  I hear what you’re saying; however, I find them to be actually quite good. The more you’re working in your codebase, the more you’ll get. And they’re suppose to be light-hearted and just something to chuckle at. As developers, our time is cut into slices and each comes with headaches. These are fun and interesting analytics about my git behavior and I’m here for it 🚀 Maybe opting out of the granular features would provide MSFT with more detailed analytics anyways? 🤷‍♂️ 🙏

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: yes again, there will be opposing views here, as in other threads too that's why GitHub allowed us to hide those achievements and make your profile private the only additional feature which is, I think, is good to have is the ability to select the badges you want to display

Answers.Author: pond
Answers.Body: Yes, if the feature is to be much use to those of us that think "Gitty Up" or "how quickly I closed a PR" or other such things are dumb and/or should simply never be gamified in any way, then a more granular approach is needed. I have the following "achievements". Ask yourself: Does the developer community want to encourage the behaviour of aiming for these achievements? And are they actually worthwhile things which are in any way difficult?  Apparently I've at some point closed a PR within 5 minutes of it being opened, which sounds more like I made a mistake rather than a useful achievement. I have merged automatically-generated Dependabot PRs by clicking on the "merge" button. I created a repository which has "many stars". Well that sounds good! Except - "many" is only 16, in this case. Oh. I have apparently opened pull requests after they were merged. I'm not sure what this means precisely but it certainly also sounds like a mistake, not an achievement. Arctic Code Vault, which is the one people seem to generally like.

Replies.Author: jdevstatic
Replies.Body: in a collaborative scenario, it can mean, all are confident to merge that within five minutes it's a tier or threshold, the next time you reach the next tier, you will receive another one, take a look at Linus Torvalds, the creator of Linux OS

Replies.Author: pond
Replies.Body: in a collaborative scenario, it can mean, all are confident to merge that within five minutes But there's no way to know that, GitHub certainly doesn't, and there is no way in any degree of even the remotest concept of professionalism that we should be encouraging people to rush PRs to a close within a few minutes, collaborative or not. it's a tier or threshold, the next time you reach the next tier, you will receive another one This is invisible but with tiers surely that just makes it even worse. It's genuinely just gamifying things and encouraging people to do bad things to game a crappy stats engine for asinine rewards. Simultaneously, it's almost discouraging if you're really into this because you have to be Linus Torvalds to get four stars! Unobtainum. Development, for those that actually enjoy it rather than just do it for a pay cheque, has its own rewards. It has its own aspects of fun, flow, achievement. We don't have to be made to feel like we're role players in a real-life Barney The Dinosaur episode to "make it fun". It's childish and patronising. Aesthetics are subjective, but seriously, an outdated style cat emoji with stars for eyes? It's just a wannabe attempt at kawaii, with all the charm of a middle-age politician trying to convince the electorate that they're "down with the kids".

Answers.Author: thenithinbalaji
Answers.Body: Yeah true.  Achievements should be displayed in a separate tab and not under the profile. It should be fully transparent, and stuff like PRs and discussions made in private repos should not count for the process. If someone chose to turn achievements off, then, Github should display the "the user has turned off achievements" message since a few people already believe that more badges = more superior. Ability to report and remove someone's badge permanently if it's not authentic. Will prevent people from asking others to star their repo or mark theirs as answers in discussions. Except for Pull Shark and Starstruck badges, the other badges do not support or promote people to contribute to open-source in any way. They must be removed. Ability to turn off certain badges rather than turning off the entire set of achievements.  If you have any other suggestions, additions, or deletions, add them in the comments. Let's make Github hear!

Replies.Author: jdevstatic
Replies.Body: that will not change anything, what's the difference between placing it in another tab and the option to hide it ? it is still gamification how about those companies that needs to have private repos ? of course they can't make it public still the same thing, it is still gamification

Replies.Author: thenithinbalaji
Replies.Body: that will not change anything, what's the difference between placing it in another tab and the option to hide it? it is still gamification It would be at least good to have them in a separate tab rather than hiding them completely. Some badges like Arctic Code Vault Contributor, Pull Shark, and Mars Rover Badge, convey your open-source skills but they don't look professional enough to have on the profile page IMO. how about those companies that needs to have private repos ? of course they can't make it public Added that because I have seen people fake Quick Draw, Pull Shark, Pair extraordinaire, Galaxy Brain, etc. in private repos, and then delete the repo. Even if Github decides to gamify stuff, there must be some level of authenticity right? I am not totally against gamification. I do like badges like Pull Shark, Arctic Code Vault Contributor, and Mars Rover Badge.

Replies.Author: pond
Replies.Body: Definitely. Certainly transparent. I realise that people want private repos to be shown but that's just gamifying from behind the barrier of closed source development, and allows people to create fake private repos which with trivial automation could easily provide a fair few of the existing badges for nothing. You want badges? Work in open source. I completely support your idea here. Yeah, "no badges" vs "you don't know because they're hidden" is a useful distinction. I'd have to hope that GitHub would have that covered and I'm not sure I like the idea of people policing each other. Unfortunately, people - especially online - are often nasty and petty and could act maliciously in this regard. Certainly things that are utterly trivial "achievements" or could represent bad behaviour are very dubious and I have no idea why they were put there, except to say that the entire feature feels like a bunch of corporate suits with not one iota of clue about actual developers, who are pushing something they speak of in terms of "increasing engagement" and "monetisation opportunities". GitHub does not need to be a social network. Please, goodness, no; we don't need any more. LinkedIn should have been warning enough. Absolutely, and surely this would be super, super easy to implement. I'm sure any one of us reading here could add a "hidden" boolean column to the database and implement a "remove" button, with full test coverage, in at most an hour or two.

Title: Achievements: don't make me click "Update preferences", just save when I click the checkbox
Author: rattrayalex
Body: I don't like achievements; I'm offended that the first things someone should see about my profile are that I "YOLO" (sorry that I merged directly to a small private repo?) and have had three PR's merged (I think I've had hundreds or thousands, but ok?). I wanted to turn it off, and found this but if you toggle the checkbox and navigate away, it doesn't save, and doesn't warn you that you have unsaved changes. Meanwhile, other checkboxes in my github settings (eg, notifications) apply atomically and are saved right away, without needing to press a button to "commit" them. For users who are upset that they've been decorated with flair, at least let them have a single click to remove it – imagine how more upset they'd be when they try to turn it off and it's still there. It feels intentionally deceptive, even though it's not. Additionally, when viewing one's own profile, there should be a button to remove this – or at least navigate to the part of the settings page to remove it – right there. I shouldn't have to go googling. EDIT: more color, because elsewhere someone said this "wasn't an issue because other UI's make you press a button to save changes": Many other parts of github's toggle-based settings save on commit, and there is no indication that your change hasn't been saved (no beforeunload handler, no changing of the button from disabled to active, etc). Even the wording "Update preferences" implied to me that it would open some other dialog about my preferences related to achievements (perhaps changing their styling or opting into certain badges or something).

Answers.Author: stevenxxiu
Answers.Body: Just a comment on how to block this from uBlock Origin: github.com##.d-block:has(a[href*="?tab=achievements"]) github.com##.d-md-block:has(a[href*="?tab=achievements"])  The only answer is for Microsoft to remove this horrid idea.

Title: Achievement: Pull requests count is incorrect
Author: ctjlewis
Body: Just noticed these on my profile - definitely have had more than 3 PRs merged though.

Answers.Author: thomscoder
Answers.Body: Hi @ctjlewis That x3 is most likely your tier.  Tier 1: Base Tier 2: Bronze Tier 3: Silver Tier 4: Gold  According to your README.md you have opened something like 100+ PR that got you to unlock the Silver rank - Tier 3. For the gold rank (Tier 4) you need around 1024+ PRs You can consult the tiering list here: https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements

Replies.Author: ctjlewis
Replies.Body: Thanks, that makes a lot more sense! “x3” text probably not the best choice from a UX standpoint.

Title: Pull requests don’t get updated
Author: NikhilMath
Body: I do not see my pull request shark ever getting updated, I am pretty sure more than 2 of my pull requests have been approved lol.

Answers.Author: linuxlawson
Answers.Body: It will only get updated for every tier (level) 2 - 16 - 128 - 1024 so if you get every tier, you will have x4 Here is a good guide: https://github.com/drknzz/GitHub-Achievements So, you will get x3 at 128 pull requests.

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: take a look at mine  it's 2 , 16 , 128

Replies.Author: NikhilMath
Replies.Body: Thank you! So should it be permanently bronze at 128 pull requests?

Replies.Author: linuxlawson
Replies.Body: At 128, it will turn to silver (x3). And when you hover over the badge, it will flip back and forth between bronze and silver, showing you completed 3 tiers (and 128 pull requests).

Title: How do i get galaxy brain?
Author: Neon-King
Body: what are the req for it?

Answers.Author: Drix10
Answers.Body: You need to Answer at least 2 discussions. Take note, you CANNOT mark your own answers to your own questions. They have to be marked by another user. Discussions should be in a public repository. There's a current bug observed by some users whereby marking your own answers can prevent you from getting the badge instead. Hope this answer has helped you, and all the best in getting the achievement! 🙂

Title: I've answered 2 discussions but they don't gave me the Galaxy Brain badge.
Author: carlos-dubon
Body: The requirement for the Galaxy Brain badge is to answer 2 discussions . But I´ve already done so and no badge was given to me. This are the discussions I´ve answered: Close submenu when clicked on submenu item? saadeghi/daisyui#826 ReactPaginate for unknown pageCount AdeleD/react-paginate#381 Is there a secret requirement to get the badge?

Answers.Author: Zerotask
Answers.Body: There is no secret requirement. Either it's scheduled and you get it in a few minutes / hours or it's a bug and you should report it directly to GitHub

Replies.Author: carlos-dubon
Replies.Body: How to report it?

Answers.Author: ale-lit
Answers.Body: I solved this problem! )  You need to unmark all your answers to your questions, as they do not count towards the reward, but only hinder (Receive `cell.data` on plugin grid-js/gridjs#993 & Doesn't run on initial rendered kodingdotninja/use-tailwind-breakpoint#3) You need to delete 1 of your already selected answers (to end up with less than 2) 😪 You need to get a new choice of your answer as the best from another participant and not in your question (so that it is 2) Bingo! 🎉

Title: I don't like the new badges

Replies.Author: aThorp96
Replies.Body: I agree. I got a YOLO badge for a PR I made on a personal repo to test some CI tooling. I don't want employers, present or future, to think I consider merging without review appropriate.

Replies.Author: MarkOates
Replies.Body: I also agree. To me, the badges now come across as if there was a product developer who wanted to add more features and there wasn't an adult around to say no. The new badges are too far, I'd revert and take some time to meditate on the importance of simplicity and focus in software development before continuing clowning forward with GitHub like it's a game platform.

Answers.Author: JKanczura
Answers.Body: They're silly, but they seem a little abnormal for a website like Github.

Answers.Author: aThorp96
Answers.Body: There are some which I think are neat and valuable, like the Arctic Code Vault or the "code on mars" one (I don't remember the real name). But things like YOLO and Pull Shark seem off brand and not necessarily something I want to advertise. It would be nice to selectively display those which one wishes.

Answers.Author: D7EAD
Answers.Body: Hi! There already exists a Bug Hunter highlight for people who find bugs on any of Github's allowed penetration testing scopes; you can learn about that particular highlight here. While it may not be a badge, it is certainly a rare item to see on someone's profile!

Replies.Author: JhonnyLusonode
Replies.Body: Hello @D7EAD , thank you for bringing this up! i´ve seen it before but it´s not really an achivements but a highlight. Usually those highlights are attributed to those who reports a vulnerability and meets the requirements of Severity Guidelines. The achivements i´m refering to it´s those visual bugs for example a bad redirect to a url, button malfunction, nav bar bugged etc.. And it would be a great idea putting like a badge with levels. The more you find your badge level ups. Some of you might think this is a waste of time or it´s to childish but i believe it would be a nice contribution to the github community.

Title: New beta badges on profile - low if any added value

Answers.Body: Hi @MichelML! Achievements are totally optional. You can turn them off under Profile settings at https://github.com/settings.

Yes, however I do agree that maybe they should be toned down just a bit to make it seem smart and minimal, yet aesthetically pleasing. Title: Why does YOLO achievement fire for your own work on single-person projects?
Author: cyrusae
Body: What is the point of marking a pull request by the owner of a project with one contributor, merged by the same person, in a context where no competing pull requests exist, as "merged without review"? There's "it's possible to do code review offsite" but this just seems next-level. e.g., this comment demonstrates that users expect it to mean I did that to someone else. I realize there's a strong possibility people will just tell me to turn off badges, and I already did, but I did not want to--I would like to participate in the silly thing if it's here, having this specific badge in context is just asinine and leaves a bad taste in my mouth. (Especially with the insistent call-to-action to "update Profile settings" on my profile after manually turning them off, in Settings.)

Answers.Author: eldare
Answers.Body: I also got the YOLO for merging "without PR" on 1 person project. The whole achievements thing on github is ridiculous. What's point of giving people the Pull Shark for 2 merges, for the one I made in 2018. The whole GitHub achievement thing is poorly executed at best.

Answers.Author: EliasAfara
Answers.Body: Can someone help me to get this badge?  Hi, to get the Galaxy Brain achievement badge, you need to fulfill the following criteria: Discussions should be in a public repository Get marked as answers to 2 or more questions The questions cannot be asked by you. In short, you cannot answer your own questions, those do not count. There's a current bug observed by some users whereby marking your own answers can prevent you from getting the badge instead. Reference: https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/20950#discussioncomment-3190178 Hope these steps help you in achieving your badge! Good luck :) More details here: https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: other than marking answers by others, you need to refrain from marking your own answers or you will not get that badge

Answers.Author: iamfoysal
Answers.Body: @jjaster10, to achieve the 'Galaxy Brain' achievement, take note of the following: Answer at least 2 discussions. Take note, you CAN NOT mark your own answers to your own questions. They have to be marked by another user. Discussions should be in a public repository. There's a current bug observed by some users whereby marking your own answers can prevent you from getting the badge instead. Hope this answer has helped you, and all the best in getting the achievement! Reference: https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/18467

Title: How to get badges?

Title: YOLO
Author: FootballPoolsHazel
Body: I'd like to report a bug, please. On my profile I have unlocked the yolo achievement on a private repository, however, when I click on the PR in question, it shows a PR that was approved by another member of staff. That person then left a comment "looks good" and then I merged. Yet, for some reason, I got the yolo badge from this. This isn't great, as merging without a PR is a big no-no in my organisation where I work, so this badge sends the wrong message to my coworkers.

Title: Why my contributions are going up and down?
Author: MitkoVtori
Body: I had 851 contributions yesterday, when my contributor pinned the project in his profile I had 423, when he unpinned it I had 851 again. And today I have 506! I haven't changed my email, I haven't deleted anything... And it tells me my private contributions are public. Why am I losing contributions? also, I lost half of my contributions, I had almost 900 and now 484

Answers.Author: DSDmark
Answers.Body: There is some case it is possibles :-  you delete any repo of yours, then you lose your contribution Commits made in a fork will not count toward your contributions. The commits were made: In the repository’s default branch (usually master) or In the gh-pages branch (for repositories with project sites) The email address used for the commits is associated with your GitHub account.

Replies.Author: MitkoVtori
Replies.Body: it's none of them. I had this contributions. Yesterday I made a co-authored pull request and get the co-authored achievement badge, but nothing happened to my contributions or commits, that was the last thing I did. After that on the next day I lost half of my commits & contributions. Also, on my contributions graph I twice had more than 100 contributions for the day, now there is written 57, 56 or smth. It could be because I deleted one private repo but it was before 1-2 weeks and nothing happened. I also renamed one project, but not deleted or haven't done anything to it, just rename it. On the picture that I send in the first message you can see it says Hyper Committer, and I am almost Ultra Committer, but I was Ultra Committer and soon I was gonna get the next level.

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: this might affect that, but I'm not very sure  as you can see, you have unverified commits in one of your repos upon checking, that's why that might change from time to time

Replies.Author: MitkoVtori
Replies.Body: Thanks, but how can I verify them?

Replies.Author: Julian-Dumitrascu
Replies.Body: You can contact GitHub about this.

Replies.Author: jdevstatic
Replies.Body: depending on your situation, for example, me, when I'm using GitHub Desktop and I did not install Git, all of the commits from GitHub Desktop are not verified, so what I did was, make a branch on GitHub and instead of pushing directly from GitHub Desktop, it will be through a pull request, that way, it's verified because I'm committing it directly on GitHub maybe this will help https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/managing-commit-signature-verification

Replies.Author: MitkoVtori
Replies.Body: Yea, I saw that when I commit from GitHub everything is verified. Thank you for the idea

Title: Bug: Stickybar never hides after using Hovercards on Profile Page
Author: Swivelgames
Body: Not entirely sure where to put this, so here it is! 😄 Setup: Go to any repo (like: https://github.com/leometzger/vue-vetur-gen ) Refresh the page, or open the page in a brand new window Reproduction Steps: Hover over the repository owner in the top left Click on the repository owner after the card appears Activate a hovercard by hovering over an Achievement or Organization Scroll slightly Expected outcome: Stickybar will remain hidden, until after both the Underline Nav and subsequently the Names Container VCard reach the top of the viewport. Actual outcome: Stickybar becomes visible immediately upon scrolling, and no longer disappears, regardless of scrollHeight NOTE: Every reproduction must first start on the Repository Detail Page. Simply refreshing the Profile page will not reproduce the issue. You must go back to the RDP and refresh the page in order to reproduce it. This suggests something is getting in a bad state whenever the router switches pages and a card is already visible(?). Though, that could be a redherring.

Answers.Author: Swivelgames
Answers.Body: And like that... poof! It's fixed!

Title: Arctic Code Vault Contributor
Author: jorgesandovalm
Body: Could you guide me about github achievements, which ones currently exist and how can I get them? Almost all of my friends have "Github Archive Program" but I can't find any information about that.

Answers.Author: thomscoder
Answers.Body: You can get Github achievements by being active in the Github/OSS community by contributing to repositories, replying in discussions and so on. Basically the more active you are the higher the chances to get one Currently there are:  YOLO (merging a commit without a code review) PULL SHARK (when your pull requests get merged) GALAXY BRAIN (when answering in discussions) PUBLIC SPONSOR (when sponsoring someone) ARCTIC CODE VAULT and probably some others I'm missing...  You can read more about that here

Title: Pull Shark achievement not showing all my merged PRs
Author: elidrissidev
Body: If you see my personal profile, the Pull Shark achievement only shows "x2" which I suppose means the count of repositories that merged my PRs?? But I know I have at least 3, including laravel/laravel . Anyways, liking this feature!

Answers.Author: wavescats
Answers.Body: Maybe this can help https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements

Answers.Author: melvincwng
Answers.Body: @elidrissidev , the Pull Shark achievement showing "x2" means that you have unlocked the 'Bronze' version of that particular achievement. In short, it means you submitted at least 16 Pull Requests to unlock that badge. For your reference:  Merge 2 PR --> unlock basic Pull Shark badge Merge at least 16 PR --> unlock 'Bronze' Pull Shark badge (this is where you're at now) Merge at least 128 PR --> unlock 'Silver' Pull Shark badge Merge at least 1048 PR --> unlock 'Gold' Pull Shark badge  For your reference, you can go to: https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements for more information Hope this helps :)

Replies.Author: elidrissidev
Replies.Body: Thanks! That clears it up for me.

Title: Pull Shark: not all PR's listed
Author: ExposedCat
Body: Just found the Beta version of Pull Shark achievement in my profile and some of my merged pull requests are not listed there. So is it a bug or there are some requirements for requests to be shown there?

Answers.Author: brianschnee
Answers.Body: The Achievement doesn't level up for every single pull request merged, there are certain numbers you need to hit in order to rank up. A list of those can be found here: https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements

Replies.Author: brianschnee
Replies.Body: For example: Pull Shark Bronze: 16 pull requests merged Pull Shark Silver: 128 pull requests merged Pull Shark Gold: 1024 pull requests merged

Replies.Author: ExposedCat
Replies.Body: Hm, yes, but all of the requests display as a chain there, does not it? I have much more than 2 requests shown there. Moreover, there are only my requests to my repos, and no any to other repos LOL :)

Answers.Author: aexvir
Answers.Body: at least for me there does seem to be some kind of bug on how it's counted, as I have hundreds of merge requests between 2016 and 2018, when I used to work at a company using github, that are not counted; github shows as my second pr some random change done in jan 2018 the only things that I can think could be messing with this are the fact that I changed my username back then, and that the organization I used to work on might not be there anymore (I left the org when I left the company, so can't tell for sure) I mean... no big deal I guess... but it's a shame that this number is not accurate; I'd have expected that GitHub should have a proper registry of how many and what merge requests have been done by a user, regardless of the change of username or the visibility of the organization

Answers.Author: vhirtham
Answers.Body: I think what causes the most confusion (at least for me) are the PRs that are shown when you hover over the achievement. These are not all the PRs that are counted but the ones that got you to the next level. Additional confusion comes from the fact that bronze, silver, and gold badge are not constantly displayed as depicted here. You only see them for a short time in the animation when hovering over the symbol. So in my case, I see the standard blue symbol with an x3 attached. When I move the mouse over the symbol I see 3 PRs mentioned and an animation I didn't pay much attention to. So I initially thought there were only 3 PRs counted. However, if you take a closer look, all those 3 PRs have a small note behind them 2nd pull request merged, 16th pull request merged, 128th pull request merged etc. Those are the numbers that get you to the next level. The mentioned PR is the one that let you progress to the next level. The animation in my profile first shows the silver badge, then the bronze badge, and finally the default symbol. So the counting seems to be correct (in my case), it is just the presentation of the badge that is somewhat unintuitive. When I visit the profile of @ExposedCat , I come to the conclusion that he was also confused by this. If you scroll down in the profile he has a small GitHub stat table that says he has merged 30 PRs. The Achievement reflects this by awarding him the bronze version (2x at the achievement symbol, the 2 "milestone PRs" listed, and a bronze badge at the start of the animation). So everything seems to be correct there. Suggestion I think all this confusion can be avoided if the badge is redesigned to be more intuitive:  the static symbol should directly reflect the current status. Show the bronze, silver, or gold image in the profile once achieved and not the default symbol with a multiplier attached to it Flip the order of the animation. IMHO it doesn't make sense to show the highest achievements just for a second and then the lowest one for the rest of the time. It should start at the lowest and raise to the current level which is then displayed continuously. This alone would probably help a lot with the confusion. Add a counter of the total PRs and maybe a target number for the next level. Place it over the "history" so that it is immediately visible how many PRs were counted. Maybe make the "history" erties a bit more descriptive: "Achived bronze status by merging his 16th pull request: LINK_TO_PR"  Here is a related suggestion in a separate topic

Replies.Author: jisaacks
Replies.Body: It may be correct for you, but it’s not for me. I merge PRs daily, I’ve been a member for over a decade. I earned my last badge 8 years ago and nothing since? You do the math, it doesn’t add up.

Replies.Author: vhirtham
Replies.Body: Didn't say that it is true in all cases. But at least for @ExposedCat, who opened this issue, it seems that he just got confused by the badge's design. In your case, I can't really tell what the problem is. GitHub has definitely some issues/bugs with its contribution counting. I have a public organization repo where this is pretty obvious. It might help if you add this stats table to your profile, at least temporarily. I think it uses the same counts and you can see how many PRs have been counted so far. Then just check if the number increases next time you merge a PR.

Answers.Author: aaronlamz
Answers.Body: Hi, to get the Galaxy Brain achievement badge, you need to fulfill the following criteria:  Discussions should be in a public repository Get marked as answers to 2 or more questions The questions cannot be asked by you. In short, you cannot answer your own questions, those do not count. There's a current bug observed by some users whereby marking your own answers can prevent you from getting the badge instead. Reference: I've answered 2 discussions but they don't gave me the Galaxy Brain badge. #18454 Hope these steps help you in achieving your badge! Good luck :)  More details here: https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements

Title: Option to hide Achievements and Sponsorships on the profile page
Author: jstolarek
Body: I just sponsored a project and now my profile page is cluttered with badges: one for sponsorship, the other for achievement. I need an option to hide these badges, especially Achievements, which are total nonsense. Worst of all, these two badges display above the list my Organizations, moving information that is important and accessed frequently to a less accessible place. In the end GitHub is a tool for doing my work and these badges make it less useful and more cluttered - Achievements in particular. I'm sure I can remove the sponsorship badge by cancelling the sponsorship, but will this remove the Achievements as well? EDIT: I realized I can hide the sponsorship information, but that still shows empty Sponsorship section on my profile and doesn't hide the Achievements.

Answers.Author: ashleygwilliams
Answers.Body: I'd like to second this request. I am not personally interested in my GitHub interactions being gamified and I find it noisy and stressful.

Replies.Author: ashleygwilliams
Replies.Body: This was not meant as an answer, but an effort to encourage attention to this...

Answers.Author: bailey

Title: Request - masking shown achievements
Author: Phosra
Body: Let's imagine a hypothetical a user who has three achievements: merging a PR without review, many stars on one of their repositories, and many pull requests merged. The user considers the first to be shameful, and the last to be not so important, yet would still like to show the second on their account. To remedy this, I propose that we may selectively show/hide unlocked achievements. May such feature be considered?

Answers.Author: Abhishek10351
Answers.Body: There is an option to disable all the badges you can try that instead.

Title: Profile Achievement Progress
Author: Glazelf
Body: Namely for the Pull Shark achievement I think it would be beneficial if there was a more detailed progress note than the level. Especially seeing the gap between level 3 and 4 being ~900 PRs, it would be usefull to have a progress bar or counter seperate from the level to indicate progress to the next level or how many PRs you have total. This may also apply to different/future achievements, Galaxy Brain has smaller steps but I feel like this would still be a good change.

Title: Issue with starstruck achievement
Author: mattrighetti
Body: Hello! I've noticed something is not okay with the starstruck achievement, I have 4 folders that have more than 16 stars but my achievement (not really care, actually) is showing a x2 and it shows only a folder on the timeline.

Answers.Author: linuxlawson
Answers.Body: 128 stars for bronze (x2) starstruck is correct. Probably only counts the highest number. You've probably seen this: https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements#achievements

Answers.Author: D7EAD
Answers.Body: The achievement will only show the repository that was the first to reach any given milestone. For instance, if you got 16 stars in one repository before all others, that would be your first on the timeline. Furthermore, if you were to have a different repository with 128 stars following that, that would be the second listed on the timeline, and so on. If you have 128 stars on one repository, and that repository was also your first to reach 16 stars, it will be listed twice.

Title: Please enable me to opt out from the achievements feature.

Title: Number of stars in the Starstruck badge seems to be wrong
Author: realamirhe
Body: It seems to be hardcoded " ⭐️ 16 stars" https://github.com/realamirhe?tab=achievements&achievement=starstruck https://github.com/realamirhe/immer-store has 56 starts https://github.com/aaronchall?tab=achievements&achievement=starstruck https://github.com/aaronchall/pythontrainer has 47 stars

Answers.Author: shaido987
Answers.Body: Yes, it's on purpose. The achievement is awarded when you have a created repository with >= 16 stars. When you reach 128 stars the bronze tier is unlocked, then silver at 512 and gold at 4096. You can see an example of how it looks with all unlocked here: https://github.com/torvalds?achievement=starstruck&tab=achievements Note that it still says 16, 128, 512, and 4096 stars even though the repository has more.

Title: Immutable Achievements: soulbound NFTs that allow open source contributors to build up their web3 reputation
Author: ivelin
Body: Background Github Achievements can be a great way to allow open source developers to build up their reputation. Tokenized reputation is one of the big themes in web3 alongside decentralized identity and proof of humanity. The soulbound NFT whitepaper framed the discussion and accelerated research. Github achievements can be a great soulbound fit. https://decrypt.co/resources/what-are-soulbound-tokens-building-blocks-for-a-web3-decentralized-society The Problem Currently Github Achievements do not seem to be immutable. It is less incentivizing for developers to strive to earn achievements knowing that they may disappear on a whim. Achievements would have more credible value if they are immutable. Once a developer earns a badge, it should become a permanent part of their dev reputation history. Solution: One option is to partner with POAP , Gitcoin, Arbitrum Nova, Immutable X, Pinata or any other credible NFT infrastructure project. Mint Github acheivements as inexpensive blockchain NFTs.

Title: GitHub Achievements are a terrible feature.
Author: librity
Body: GirHub Achievements are an unnecessary gamification that doesn't help asses the performance/dedication/talent/achievement of a developer. They indicate mostly meaningless things that happen at random while using github, and most can be earned in a weekend. The only achievement that actually means anything is Statstruck because it measures something objectively good about your repos. I wish they made achievements that show open-source contributions, or lines of code written per day. That's something I would be glad to show other people.

Answers.Author: linuxlawson

Title: galaxy barin achievement problem
Author: Nayab007
Body: I'm trying to get galaxy brain achievement. I have try to use different accounts.i have try to awnwers different discuions from different accounts. I have anwer more than 2 different topics. But still I'm not able to get galaxy barin achievement. Any idea what is going on with this issue?

Answers.Author: toufiqul-hasan
Answers.Body: Answer at least 2 discussions. Take note, you CANNOT mark your own answers to your own questions. They have to be marked by another user. Discussions should be in a public repository. Also if you mark answers to your own questions, there could be a bug whereby the achievement won't show despite having >=2 answers marked by other users. Reference: https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/18454 Also, please provide a couple of hours (or maybe up to a day) for your new achievements to show. If they haven't shown by then, perhaps you did not hit some "hidden" criteria. In most cases, developers seem to get their achievements instantly though. Contact 'Github Support' if you face any issues.

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: and if you already marked your answer in the past, remove that then after removing that, that's the only time it will start counting, once you have 2 discussions answered and marked by another user, ( again, this is after you removed those marked answers by yours), then that's the only time you will have that

Title: Achievement / Badges, just why??
Author: Rellotscrewdriver
Body: NOTE: I'll be mostly referring badges/achievements as achievements in this post who thought it was a good idea to add achievements? as this will become a VERY good way for people to spam it to gain achievements. and I suspect these achievements will feel cluttered on the left side of the profile page once someone achieved a lot of badges. if the majority of people like this feature, I hope you add an option to disable showing achievements to anyone(yourself and other people) on the profile page and to whoever proposed this: github is NOT a video game! I'm fine having achievements in games but not in platforms where people download open-source software or/and contribute to it! not every software needs achievements fool

Answers.Author: AlexWinder
Answers.Body: Achievements have been on profiles for some time now, only recently have they been extended. That said you can disable them from being displayed on your profile at https://github.com/settings/profile Scroll to the bottom and you can disable them.

Replies.Body: Thank you for sharing this – note that you have to click "Update preferences" to apply the change. I filed an issue about this here: #18671

Replies.Author: AlexWinder
Replies.Body: I'm not so sure that I would call that an issue, this behaviour is no different to lots of websites where you need to confirm your action before it's made. I think the issue is more of people complaining about the names/styling of the achievements rather than the struggle to hide them.

Replies.Author: rattrayalex
Replies.Body: It isn't a bug, but I do think it's a problem. I'll add more detail in #18671

Replies.Author: stevenxxiu
Replies.Body: This doesn't solve the issue. Need an option to disable everyone's achievements from being shown.

Answers.Author: stevenxxiu

Like the idea of training Copilot on open source code, it's just gonna slowly move everyone away from GitHub.
