Answers.Author: spenserblack
Answers.Body: I hope they add more "boolean achievements" instead of "numerical achievements." Looking at video games, fun achievements are often "boolean," meaning you either did or didn't do it -- there isn't a "halfway done" point. For example, "beat the secret boss" is boolean, and "collect 1,000,000 gold" is numerical. Basically, if you have to "grind" for the achievement, it's not that fun IMO. I'm not sure what that means for GitHub, but I think as an example "Contributed to a repository owned by GitHub", which is accessible and also not repetitive.

Title: Pull shark achievement should work for repositories I don't own only
Author: kudadam
Body: I just created a branch on one of my repositories to make an update, after merging it, I realized the pull shark achievement counter increased. I retried it again and realized the counter just kept on increasing. The point is, this doesn't actually make the achievement feel real enough, we will always merge our own pull requests but not everyone will merge our pull request and that's the point. If someone merges our pull request, then it means it worthy to them hence it becomes an achievement for us

Answers.Author: MrKrishnaAgarwal
Answers.Body: True, Some people create commits in their own repositories with pull requests. I also follow this.

Answers.Author: FilipeChagasDev
Answers.Body: I also received the Pull Shark achievement for a pull request I made in a repository I manage. I made this pull request and merged it on my own repository to learn how pull requests work on github. It makes no sense that I get an achievement for this.

Replies.Author: kudadam
Replies.Body: Yeah, very true

Replies.Author: hsleonis
Replies.Body: Agreed.

Answers.Author: trackpadpro
Answers.Body: I fully agree. Also, though, how does pull shark even count anything? Is it telling me that I have only had 2 PRs merged? The most I have seen anyone have yet is bronze at 2, but it doesn't make sense, because I have definitely opened far more in other repositories. I feel like these achievements should encourage people to contribute to open source projects that aren't their own, but the only 2 PRs I get credit for are one in my own repo and one in a repo that an org I am a member of owns. EDIT: Okay, fine, I figured out what it means by x2. Just second stage, and you have giant gaps between stages in an exponential fashion. That makes it a little better, I guess, but I still believe it should be pull requests that you could not merge yourself. It would be a much better badge if it instead encouraged contributing to different repos. Even that wouldn't even be fantastic because you could be encouraging people who work on a labor of love to instead ditch something they've contributed a great deal to.

Replies.Author: MrKrishnaAgarwal
Replies.Body: Agree👍

Replies.Author: Kage0923
Replies.Body: Agree

Answers.Author: atosinu
Answers.Body: Seems you have to create PR for public repositories. If you are just creating PR on private repo, it may not work for it. Then you should enable activity visible for private repositories.

Replies.Body: I don't really get what you're saying here. Are you telling us to all set our personal repos private? Because that is what it sounds like to me, but that is even more anti-open source than the badge concept in the first place. The only good one is Mars Helicopter.

Answers.Author: KOLANICH
Answers.Body: I think pull shark achievement should be removed at all. Giving achievements for just doing the things the platform is intended for is just ridiculous. Having an achievement for sending less than 10 prs is extremely ridiculous. I think this achievement should be removed and instead a small and simple counter of cumulative (in all the repos and orgs) prs, issues, commits, repos, stars, follows, forks and dependent packages should be added. Just statistics, no achievement for this. If GH wants to gamify a bit, clicking should open a plot of PDF and a text description like "more/less than of GitHub population". Everything should work without JavaScript.

Replies.Author: Nukesor
Replies.Body: I like this approach. The limits of those achievements also seem kind of arbitrary and they don't offer much value without some context. In-built statistics however (visibility can of course be toggled), would be super nice. I really like @KOLANICH 's idea on how to introduce some "soft" gamification as well.

Title: Get rid of "Galaxy Brain" and "YOLO" Achievements

Body: Galaxy Brain is encouraging spam posts in this repository, and YOLO encourages contributing to open source software without other's review.

Answers.Body: Click on your profile icon (top-right) -> settings -> public profile ->Profile settings -> turn off "Show achievements on my profile".

They do give you the option of not showing them on your profile though (like @BorislavChernev pointed out). Take a look at the discussions and you can see tons of spam posts from people trying to get galaxy brain.

Title: Confusion regarding "Pull Shark" achievement
Author: thecodeah
Body: I'm a bit confused regarding the "Pull Shark" achievement. It claims I've only opened 2 PR's that have been merged, however, that couldn't be further from reality. Initially I thought that this was maybe just limited to public repositories, so I checked out a co-workers page, and surprisingly the PR's that he has made to the exact same private repository that I have made a bunch of PR's to were taken into account. Is this a bug or am I misunderstanding something? I can absolutely assure you that I've merged more than 2 PR's to the master / main branch since I've started using Github in 2016. ( Example 1 , Example 2 ) My achievement Coworkers achievement Viewed from incognito mode to hide repository name.

Answers.Author: ElijahPepe
Answers.Body: The Pull Shark achievement is ranked by how many pull requests you've merged; x1 signifies that you've merged at least 2 pull requests, x2 signifies that you've merged at least 16 pull requests, and x3 signifies that you've merged at least 128 pull requests.

Replies.Author: thecodeah
Replies.Body: Thanks! That makes sense

Replies.Author: Zeex
Replies.Body: Isn't it supposed to count pull requests that you opened and someone else have merged? "Name> opened pull requests that have been merged" Or am I reading it wrong?

Replies.Author: lisenet
Replies.Body: @Zeex you can merge your own pull requests.

Answers.Author: alfiedotwtf
Answers.Body: So does that mean x4 @ 65536? I think I speak for @thecodeah and expected that xN should be where N = the number of actual PRs merged

Replies.Author: lisenet
Replies.Body: @alfiedotwtf x4 @ 1024 I think. x1 - 2 PRs x2 - 16 (2 * 8) PRs x3 - 128 (2 * 8 * 8) PRs x4 - 1024 (2 * 8 * 8 * 8) PRs x5 - 8192 (2 * 8 * 8 * 8 * 8) PRs and so on...

Replies.Author: alfiedotwtf
Replies.Body: 🤦 that was a brain fart on my part... for some reason my brain was thinking: x1 - bit x2 - nibble x3 - byte x4 - word etc, but yeah, I was off by one there

Replies.Author: quoideneuf
Replies.Body: I came here wondering the same thing :)

Replies.Author: bernhardreiter
Replies.Body: It seems that x4 is 1024, see example https://github.com/ljharb found by Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements#2 (comment) .

Answers.Author: HBL001
Answers.Body: How do I turn these "achievements" off?

Replies.Author: lisenet
Replies.Body: Navigate to https://github.com/settings/profile and untick the box that says "Show Achievements on my profile".

Title: Starstruck should apply to repos you're a contributor to, rather than ones you create.
Author: wiki-Bird
Body: If you're a major contributor to a starred repository, I don't think it makes sense than an owner account gets the achievement yet you don't. There are repos I've worked on (and not owned) where I've done more work than the account which owns it, and repos I've owned in which other people have done more work than I. Because of this, I think starstruck should apply to repos you're a contributor to, rather than ones you create.

Title: Disable Achievements
Author: allo-
Body: Is there a way to disable the achievements function? I was fun to have a badge arctic vault contributor and maybe even the mars achievement. But now all kind of trivial things is added. No, I don't need a badge for my first pull request. And I don't need a badge for having a repo with some stars either. I would really appreciate an option to disable that section on the profile.

Answers.Author: xanderyzwich
Answers.Body: Or the ability to choose which achievements are visible.

Replies.Author: allo-
Replies.Body: This coupled with an option "add by default" or "disabled by default", so one doesn't have to hide new ones from time to time. As said, some were funny, but now Github looks like it wants to be a game. You don't only get an achievement for a pull request, but you also unlock "bronze" and get a counter how many you opened, and finally it has a silly name like "Pull Shark". I don't want to be the no-fun-allowed guy and publish most software for fun, but a code platform shouldn't be too playful, but a simple to use tool that makes it easy to focus on what you want to do.

Replies.Author: allo-
Replies.Body: Looks like there is a switch. Maybe you open another issue for selecting which ones to show.

Answers.Author: airtower-luna
Answers.Body: You can disable the achievements section on your profile, see here: https://docs.github.com/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-managing-your-github-profile/managing-contribution-settings-on-your-profile/showing-your-private-contributions-and-achievements-on-your-profile#changing-the-visibility-of-achievements

Title: "Public Sponsor" Badge Suggestions
Author: ajmeese7
Body: I have several notes and suggestions about the "Public Sponsor" profile badge: Whenever you sponsor a new person, the badge currently replaces your "1st sponsorship" with them. I have sponsored various individuals over the years, but my "1st sponsorship" is now someone that I have only sponsored for a month. Past sponsorships are not included, so " @ajmeese7 is sponsoring 4 organizations or users." does not acknowledge the other users I have supported over the years that I am not a current sponsor of. I would like to see the message change to something along the lines of " @ajmeese7 is currently sponsoring 4 organizations or users and has sponsored a total of 11." One idea is the inclusion of a tier system like with many of the other badges for total users/organizations sponsored. Tiers could be 1, 4, 16, and 64 users or something along those lines, to give additional recognition if a user has been financially supporting a large number of other users. This could also be for number of months or something, it does not necessarily have to be on a per-user/org basis. Having a display of the profile pictures of all the users/orgs that a user has financially supported over the years, possibly with a hover feature indicating the total months sponsoring that person and the overall monetary contribution.

Answers.Author: paradox-bd
Answers.Body: Maybe this can help https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements

Replies.Author: ajmeese7
Replies.Body: Help with what ?

Title: Selective hide/show badges?
Author: jtakalai
Body: Some of the badges could be considered less... prestigious. Yes, I merged a branch without waiting for reviews, does this mean I need to be firebranded with a YOLO achievement? :D This one is harmless, to me, but still: these achievements aren't necessary positive in all circumstances to all people, and showing them in the public profile non-consensually feel just wrong. Achievement badges should be opt-in to show, not opt-out, and definitely not mandatory. TL;DR: consider not showing achievement badges at all by default adding them as an option to enable in the profile settings page

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: yes you have the option to disable that, even make your profile private, the only thing that's not available is to select what badges you want to be displayed https://github.com/settings/profile

Answers.Author: bever1337
Answers.Body: It's an incredibly unprofessional sounding achievement. Sometimes it's reasonable to merge without a review, sometimes that would get a developer fired. This is an opt-out system, so developers may have no reason to opt-out until GitHub gives them a tactless achievement. My request: GitHub achievements should only cast developers in a positive light.

Replies.Author: kospl
Replies.Body: I bet single developers don't get (meaning understand) this badge at all.

Answers.Author: bever1337
Answers.Body: Related discussion here: https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/18542

Title: Merge badges from multiple emails.
Author: TrevorBenson
Body: I used the Merging Multiple Personal Accounts to merge my work email into my personal account. I also went through the list of Why are my contributions not showing up on my profile? and starred to all the work repositories which my work email had made commits in. I also restored my GPG and SSH keys and have SSO authorized the SSH. I'm only seeing the badges from the personal account, is this expected behavior? Does the entire commit graph need to finish rebuilding first? Will I just have to re-earn any badges which I no longer have? I did notice that after starring all the private repositories of the organization there are still ~400 attributions missing even when I'm signed into the Orgs SSO. Signing into the Org SSO has a minimal impact on total contributions. I recall that combined I was around 650-750 contributions for the year with a bit below/above 200 in personal and 400+ in the Org. Now its ~240 total: 243 Not logged in / Incognito looking at profile: 242 Logged into account, but not Org SSO: 243 Logged into account and Authenticated to SSO: My suspicion is the missing contributions are why badges are missing. Are there any suggestions on investigating missing contributions? Or maybe tracking down all contributions for a deleted/ghost account to try and compare which ones are not in my graph?

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: badges are linked to email accounts, did you add all of them under one account ? but I'm not very sure if, say, you have both and it will be duplicated on the account you have now also, as I was checking your profile, I see this  your last public activity was 2021 and they are your repos, most of those in your Repos tab are forks and you already read the rules for that because you shared the link, what else might you be missing ? oh I checked that again, they are just 2-3 commits missing ? I thought you are losing, say 100 commits difference

Replies.Author: TrevorBenson
Replies.Body: badges are linked to email accounts, did you add all of them under one account ? Yep. I had 2 accounts each with 1 email. Now both emails are attached and verified under this one account. The missing commits went into private Org repos, not personal ones. I have starred each of those repos after merging/verifying the email to this account. The deleted account had maybe 5 personal repositories, but had minimal commits/merges. Maybe 10-20 contributions would be lost from allowing those personal repositories to be deleted. what else might you be missing ? I don't know, that is why I am asking here. :) they are just 2-3 commits missing ? No, hundreds. There were 350-450 commits in the work account before deletion. I recall reviewing 2022 commits for both accounts last week and the combined total was around 650-700 and I presumed 800-1000 would be my end of year totals. For comparison I just went and unstarred 6 of the Org private repositories. I worked on each of these repositories in the last 3 months, and definitely many many times this year. There should be at least 100 commits related to these repositories, if not at least 200-300. My graph still shows I have 243 commits for 2022, identical to the number of contributions before unstarring these repos. If I choose to expand my Contribution Activity the Organizations repositories do not showup at all, as if I had never contributed in any way except from my personal email address.

Answers.Author: TrevorBenson
Answers.Body: I picked one of the smaller repositories and reviewed the history. I can see a merge/commit into the default branch from July 21st of this year, and 7 contributions for this year.  I double checked the commit .patch URL as well and this confirms the work email is definitely linked to this specific commit. However under the contribution graph July 21st says 0 contributions. My total contributions say 243. I remove the star from this repository and 5 others which would have much greater contributions than this example. 10 minutes later my contributions still say 243. So even though it has linked past contributions to my current account which has the email attached, they do not appear to be included in contribution graphs regardless of adding a ⭐ to the repository or not and I can clearly see things attributed to my current account for specific dates are showing as 0 for that same date in my profile.

Answers.Author: TrevorBenson
Answers.Body: Solved, got some of my contributions back, but just a fraction. I gave examples of matching the contribution requirements still and of a url, .patch and missing dates in the graph to github support, they recalculated contributions for those repositories. However I was still missing over 1/2 of the contributions. It turns out when the merging accounts page stated:  To attribute past commits to the new account, add the email address you used to author the commits to the account you're keeping. For more information, see "Why are my contributions not showing up on my profile?"  One should infer (although I did not at the time) that Pull Requests, Issues and Discussions will not be attributed to the new account. Unfortunately since this was not explicitly stated in either page I presumed that I could get back all contributions. If this was more clearly stated I might have decided initially to not create two accounts and later try to merge them. I hope this discussion helps others better understand the ramifications of merging accounts on past contributions.

Title: Actions and Packages - Check in
Author: Akash1134
Body: Hello everyone and hope you’re having a great October so far. We’re back with the latest from the Actions and Packages world. 🌎 We'd love to hear your feedback on GitHub Larger Hosted Runners Beta . Please fill out this short, anonymous survey to help my team understand your experience & opportunities for improvement. @lkfortuna is leading the efforts to take your feedback to the future product ships. For more information, please visit this discussion. 💯 Introducing Actions on GitHub Mobile 📱 😲 Yes, you heard it right! Actions are coming to GitHub Mobile! From a tap 🤌 to viewing and reviewing pull requests to defining a workflow-run on the go, 🚶 we’ve got you covered! Read more about GitHub Mobile and send us your feedback to help us improve. Got more feedback to share? ☑️ You can contribute to several GitHub projects including GitHub Docs by participating in this year's Hacktoberfest . If you’ve ever wanted to contribute to GitHub’s open source documentation, now is your chance! ✌️ From the Community - Citizens on a Roll! 🎢 Multiple posts by @antonblr had me read 👀 almost all of their contributions in the community and here are a few examples of their workmanship. Here’s a recent thread in which @antonblr provided a great solution to @scarf005's question Well Done! 👏 Solved ✅ another one in collaboration with a great suggestion by @ChristopherHX 🤝 This one is a masterpiece 🥇 with links to all the docs that @dpo would ever need fort workflows. We’re not done with @antonblr's contributions yet, another gem 💎 with a one liner solution. This is great! @ChristopherHX has been providing some amazingly descriptive ✍️ answers in the community. @kuisathaverat has been looking to define an environment variable Global to a job but did not use the correct environment which @ChristopherHX did in his really well crafted solution. 💯 Sharing the updated info ℹ️ with the author of actionlint . @rhysd was not sure about an indented behavior of reusable workflow. @ChristopherHX helped with a detailed response and his documentation is spot on! 🏅 Let’s look at this self-solve ✔️ by @schalkneethling realizing that the default GITHUB_TOKEN would’ve solved the error. Thanks for coming back and updating the discussion. ⚡ GitHub Universe - Agenda is Live! 🌐 We’re super excited 😮 for GitHub Universe and the countdown 📅 has begun. It is less than a month from now and we have the list of agenda on our hands. You will have the chance to explore 80+ content sessions delivered by over 120 different speakers, across two days and four content tracks, all designed to level up your skills. Read more about the agenda here . To get even more excited check out the two great ways to experience everything GitHub Universe has to offer this year from @lclindeman 🚀 From the Release Radar 🚨 GitHub Actions: Deprecating save-state and set-output commands 🆕 FYI, to avoid untrusted logged data to use set-state and set-output workflow commands without the intention of the workflow author we have introduced a new set of environment files to manage state and output. Here’s more details on the change. GitHub Actions: GitHub Actions: larger Hosted Runners now support -latest tag 🏷️ GitHub now supports using the -latest image label on your larger hosted runners. With the -latest label developers can be sure that their workflows use the latest available GA image in GitHub Actions. Are you interested in learning more about larger hosted runners? Read the announcement here or sign up for the beta here . 📢 GitHub Actions: Jobs running on macos-latest are now running on macOS 12 🖱️ This is a much anticipated change, and over the next 10 weeks, jobs using the macos-latest runner label will migrate from macOS 11 to 12. You just need to include runs-on: macos-latest in your jobs. Packages: Consolidated owner and admin role 📦 We’re merging identical privileges that the admin role and original poster of the package used to have into a single authority to ease out the overall process. So, now by default, both the original publisher and the organization owner will have admin privileges on that package. Checkout this document to know more. ☮️

Title: Happy Hacktober [New to GitHub Check-in]
Author: queenofcorgis
Body: The most known holiday in October may be Halloween, but in the open source world, the biggest event is Hacktoberfest! What is Hacktoberfest ? Digitalocean’s annual event for nine years running that celebrates open source contributions, giving back to projects that don’t have the resources to expand, and expand your skills ✏️ . There are ways to get involved even with low/non-code contributions as well. The perfect way to jumpstart your GitHub journey is by participating in this much-loved month-long event. Check out the details below ⬇️ . 🌟 Community Superstars : A round of applause for these community citizens 👏 @WabashFan for not only giving tons of background information in their question , but coming back to self-solve it as well - nice ​​! @welkeyever : Asked a great question on the dependency graph and included THREE examples - help them out by answering! @sailingthroughemotion : is new to GitHub and Pages, but they’re already trying out some new themes! Kudos to you and if anyone can help out on why their theme disappeared - dive in 🤿 . 👻 ‘Tis the Season : Hacktoberfest has started and we’ve got you covered 💻 How to Get Ready : @mishmanners ’s guide to getting started in Hacktoberfest 2022 ✅ ! Expand your open source contributions : This year, we’re encouraging more than code contributions: writing, design, advocacy, and financial donations 💖 . Learn more from @abbycabs . Hacktoberfest Repositories : Looking to get on the action? @OtacilioN has you covered with their curated list of Hacktoberfest 2022 repositories. There is even a section of repositories great for beginners! 🆕 What’s new in GitHub : Around the product and the Community, the latest. Private Profiles 🔒 : An oft-requested feature, private profiles are now generally available . Learn how to set your profile to private here . 🗳️ Introducing the Repositories Category : Repositories now has its own category in Community on Discussions, use it to ask questions, share feedback, and collaborate on all things GitHub repository-related. Local Time Zones Available on Profiles 🕰️ : Profile personalization continues with this latest rollout . GitHub Skill 🆙 : Expand your GitHub skillset each week with @ossanna16 , this week create your profile README 📖 . How are you celebrating Hacktoberfest, the changing of the seasons, or just that you’ve gotten started with GitHub? We want to know in the comments.

Title: The difference between forking and cloning a repository on GitHub
Author: fernandez
Body: Cloning and forking repositories on GitHub One of the main benefits of using a version control system is the ability to acquire your own copy of a project quickly and easily. The two most commonly used methods for copying a repository on GitHub are cloning and forking . Tip: If you just need an archive of repository contents, click the Code button on its home page and look for Download ZIP . What is cloning? Repositories created on GitHub exist as remotes . When you clone a repository you are creating a local copy on your computer that you can sync with the remote on GitHub. Cloning is ideal for contributing directly to a repository alongside other users while utilizing branching and other collaboration tools to manage changes. Tip: Cloning a repository can be used to create a backup that is regularly kept up to date, but it's important to note that although your clone will copy over Git data like files and commit history, it won't bring over issues, pull requests, and other GitHub elements. To clone, head to the main page of a repository and click the green Code button. In the dropdown that appears you will have the option to clone over HTTPS , SSH , or by using the GitHub CLI . What about forking? A fork is a copy of a repository that allows you to make your own changes without impacting the original project. A fork differs from a cloned copy in that it doesn't allow for direct collaboration with the root using local commands like git push and git pull . Instead, your fork exists on GitHub and you can contribute back to the original project using Pull Requests . You can also synch your fork easily to keep it up-to-date with changes from the root repository. Forks are ideal for situations where the root repository is serving as a basis for further iteration, or to play around with ideas -- instead of starting a project from scratch you can use an existing repository as a foundation then take it to the next level! Tip: Keep in mind when working with a fork of a private repository that GitHub will consider the owner of the root repository to have ownership of its forks as well. This means that when a private repository is deleted any of its forks will also be removed. This isn't something to worry about for public repositories as in that case the fork is owned by the fork owner and will be detached or re-routed in the case a root is deleted. Forking a project is as easy as clicking the Fork button in the header of the repository home page. Once the process is complete you'll be taken to your forked copy where you can start collaborating! Forking a repository will copy data such as files and code but Issues, branches, pull requests and other features won't join the party. Instead, your fork will start the same way as a newly created repository so you can begin work on it as a fresh project. Further Reading Now that you know which method to use when making a new copy of a project, here are some other resources for getting comfortable working with forks and clones: Understanding the GitHub Flow Configuring a remote for a fork Which remote URL should I use?

Answers.Author: mukeshsolanki
Answers.Body: I have a few decent repositories with decent stars. Here's how I get traction with these repos. On Github  Make sure the repository is well maintained. Documentation is key make sure the readme file has details required to use your lib, SDK etc... and yeah make sure also throw in screenshots to show off any UI if your repo provides them. Use badges. This will help identify the env and the min, max and current version of the repo.  External Sources  Write a blog post about the problem at hand and how the repo, lib, SDK etc... solves the issue. Share them on linked in, twitter, and other socials. (I usually don't share the repo instead I share the blog post which makes for better SEO so google picks it up faster :P )

Title: Pull Shark stopped showing public details when I let it also show private ones
Author: ediosyncratic
Body: In the pull shark badge, before I allowed display of private details, I could see two cfengine pull requests listed; but once (prompted to do so by a pop-up) I'd enabled display of private details, it no longer shows the details of those, they're just as "inaccessible" as the third that's been added. In any case, although it would make sense to not give details to others of private repository pull requests, it could at least show me those details ! Arguably anyone with access to a private repository should be able to see the entries relating to that repo in my pull shark details.

Answers.Author: ediosyncratic
Answers.Body: If what's happening is that, now that I allow private repo details to be mentioned, the pull requests that qualified me for a badge are private ones, where previously a public pull request served that purpose, then perhaps the thing to do is:  if I've qualified in public requests for a badge, show the public request that qualified me for it, at least to users not able to see the private request that would otherwise have qualified me for it; only show the "inaccessible" for badge-qualifying events if I've only qualified for it by counting private pull requests; and maybe even then show the first public pull request after that instead, to anyone who can't see the repo the private one was in.

Replies.Author: linuxlawson
Replies.Body: Yes

Answers.Body: @azvast These profile templates should be able to help you! https://github.com/durgeshsamariya/awesome-github-profile-readme-templates https://github.com/topics/profile-readme https://github.com/topics/profile-template

Answers.Author: svintit
Answers.Body: Feel free to use mine as a starting point if you would like!

Answers.Author: manasesjesus
Answers.Body: TLDR; Create a repo named as your username (azvast) and add a README. The info in your readme will be displayed on your profile. You can use this tool to generate the contents of your readme, and this one to add your statistics. Here's GitHub's step-by-step profile README tutorial. Another approach is using GitHub Actions to update your readme whenever an event triggers the action. There are actions such as this, this, and many more. You can add all the info you want to make it handsome. You can also code your own action using GitHub GraphQL and REST APIs to get the info you want, and update the readme with that info. It can be displayed in SVG and you can use CSS for colors and animations. Take a look at my profile to see this approach. Finally, take a look at this repository as it has a collection of readme profiles. You may get inspiration by looking at different profiles.

Title: New achievements are counterproductive
Author: rossjrw
Body: I'm seeing a couple of new achievements in my profile. They are: 'YOLO': seemingly for merging pull requests without reviews 'Pull Shark': for having opened pull requests that have since been merged. Having achievements displaying on a user page always risks giving the impression that the user actively sought out those achievements; that they are an 'achievement hunter'; that they endorse and are proud of whatever achievements are displaying. That's not the case with these achievements - they don't reward any special behaviour, only arbitrary numbers and activities. They don't give the impression that I'm a professional developer, but that I'm a novice coder who's just finished my first project. A potential employer glancing at my profile, perhaps unfamiliar with this very niche GitHub-specific feature, might assume a negative impression of me. These specific achievements only emphasise my issue. As a developer I don't particularly want to have YOLO and a shark face plastered on my profile - I feel that they might be of more interest to a demographic far younger than me. The achievement names seem to support this - 'Galaxy Brain' referring to a meme and 'YOLO' being another meme, albeit a decade old. (I don't know if 'Pull Shark' is a reference to anything, but I assume that it is, because it doesn't mean anything to me otherwise.) But even beyond the theme, these achievements don't encourage positive behaviours. As anyone who's tried to set up KPIs on a bunch of developers will tell you, it's really difficult to measure and reward developer progress numerically. 'Pull Shark' for example incentivises opening pull requests, but not, say, opening good or useful pull requests (it does require that the pull requests are eventually merged, which is a nice touch). 'YOLO' appears to be a one-off, which is far better than incentivising creating and merging pull requests in a junk repository with reckless abandon - but in that case, what's the point of rewarding that at all? 'Pull Shark' is especially reductive: it displays on my profile as "Pull Shark x 3", which could be read as my having merged 3 pull requests - but clicking into it reveals that I've actually merged at least 128, with the number in the achievement title seemingly being found by $\lfloor \log(4 *n) /( 3 * log(2)) \rfloor$ where $n$ is the PR count - if that's the case, I could have merged anywhere between 128 and 1023 pull requests and this achievement wouldn't care. To compare these to the two extant achievements that I'm aware of: 'Arctic Code Vault Contributor': not a useful achievement, because it's more of an advertisement for something that GitHub is doing than something the user has done specifically. Practically everyone active in open source has it - no personal value 'Mars Helicopter 2020 Contributor': describes something discrete and meaningful, and acts as a community rallying point. Really cool. An excellent achievement with genuine personal value - I wish I had it! Overall, my feedback for the new achievements (those that I'm aware of, anyway), is that they are not particularly useful and even a little harmful. I feel that new achievements should reward specific achievements rather than hitting arbitrary quotas.

Answers.Author: ssb22
Answers.Body: Likewise, I got the arctic code vault badge and 2 "pull sharks" and I set them to not display. I might not mind so much if they were displayed less prominently, especially on mobile view where the default place is above your popular or pinned repositories (I think repositories are more important than badges, so I don't want anyone to have to scroll down past badges before they can start to see my repositories). Still I'm glad that they can be turned off in the profile settings.

The pull shark from a distance (I'm kind of old) looked like some kind of a scary ghost, skull or monster. Plus, some contributors (if they figure out the pull shark is actually a shark) might sincerely be afraid of sharks, or similar attributes. I think the symbology of the emblem chosen for this award sends off the wrong vibe. I'm also sceptical of the one with the brain. What does it mean to not get the brain? Does it mean differentiation regarding cognitive ability? This is too competitive and might be offensive in certain occasions. I understand that achievements need themes, but is there any way to choose more neutral themes. The pink unicorn whtn GHA is full loaded seems OK for me. Hardly anyone is afraid of unicorns. Maybe ther is another idea with less potential for fear/comparison/competitive negativeness...?

Title: pull request achievement number
Author: chakravala
Body: if you're going to use powers of 2 to increment the "level" of a user's pull request achievement, then please use powers of 2 properly: 2^0 1 2^1 2 2^2 4 2^3 8 2^4 16 2^5 32 2^6 64 2^7 128 2^8 256 2^9 512 2^10 1024 level 0 badge should be 1 merged pull request, level 1 is two merged, level 2 is 4 merged, and so on, this is more meaningful / realistic

Answers.Author: cervonwong
Answers.Body: There are only four tiers per achievement for simplicity. I assume that's why they skipped some of the powers of 2 in between and used the scale 2, 16, 128, and 1024 instead.

Answers.Author: melvincwng
Answers.Body: @chakravala, for "Pull Shark" achievement badge, it goes by 2 PRs, 16 PRs, 128 PRs, 1024 PRs. Essentially, 2^1, 2^4, 2^7, 2^10. Hope this clarifies Reference: https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements

Replies.Author: cervonwong
Replies.Body: It is not arbitrary and don't be too quick to call it garbage. Having just 4 tiers might make each tier more significant and distinctive. And the jump from 16 to 128 to 1024 makes it harder for a person to get to the next tier, making it more impressive. Though, your suggestion of having powers of 2 might also work too, but it's just not what GitHub chose to do.

Title: More profile badges
Author: 3kh0
Body: This is something I wanted for a long time but I have seen the GitHub badges and I wish there was more you can get. Here are some ideas for new ones, Co-pilot acquired! (if you are in the GitHub co-pilot program) A Grand Star (get 1k stars on a repo you own) A Grand following (get 1k followers on your account) Time traveler! (Hav activity on your account before github.com was registered as a domain) Creative Mind (suggest an idea that gets implemented) That's why you don't get nice things! (reports a very damaging bug to support) Still learning! (is in the GitHub student program) This is not the most you could add but if this gets added that would be really cool!

Answers.Author: Sagar-Sharma-7
Answers.Body: Hello @marcellomaterializelabs After changing your username, your old username becomes available for anyone else to claim. Title: Pull Shark badge not updating!

Title: How to get the Galaxy Brain achievement badge?
Author: alexanderzzzz
Body: How to get the Galaxy Brain achievement badge?

Answers.Author: aaronlamz
Answers.Body: Hi, to get the Galaxy Brain achievement badge, you need to fulfill the following criteria:  Discussions should be in a public repository Get marked as answers to 2 or more questions The questions cannot be asked by you. In short, you cannot answer your own questions, those do not count. There's a current bug observed by some users whereby marking your own answers can prevent you from getting the badge instead. Reference: I've answered 2 discussions but they don't gave me the Galaxy Brain badge. #18454 Hope these steps help you in achieving your badge! Good luck :)  More details here: https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements

Replies.Author: alexanderzzzz
Replies.Body: thanks!

Title: Pull Shark? That's pretty patronizing. I do this for a living.
Author: blanketcat
Body: I don't want badges, I don't want a social network, I want a place to store my code. This isn't an afterschool club for me. I do this for a living. F---ing "Pull Shark"? Patronizing. I'm almost 40. I don't need little dopamine hits when I'm working on code, I'm working on code, that's what I do for dopamine. I don't want the services I'm using to RECOGNIZE AND REACT TO WHAT I'M DOING AT ALL. Stop paying attention. I want the services I'm using to function. I want stupid services that work. Hopefully well. Services are not my friends, they're services. This isn't a playground, it's where I work. I notice it says beta next to the badge. So now you're pushing me into beta programs without asking me if I want to participate. Bold move. I already don't want to use Github after using all of the code you've collected over the years for the AI code assistant that I would have to pay for even though our work made it possible. GITHUB. STOP. ALL. OF. THIS. I don't have a facebook account. I don't have a snapchat account. I don't have a tiktok account. Why are you ruining this? The git server I host at home doesn't do any of this. I don't want to put it behind DynDNS and deal with setting up the firewall, auth etc. That's all Github is. It takes care of some annoying things for me. If it becomes more annoying than the problems it solves, it ceases to be a viable alternative to just doing it myself. Bitbucket and Gitlab don't do any of this social media marketing nonsense. WHY. ARE. YOU. DOING. THIS? This does not improve anything fundamental to the service. Look, my work uses github. I don't want to use a different service for work and personal projects if I can possibly help it, I have enough context switching with OS, text editor, and frameworks. Please, I'm soooo close to switching, and I don't want to. I don't want to learn another UI. I don't want to update my .gitconfig username and walk away, BUT I WILL IF I LAND IN ONE MORE BETA. You looking for a strong reaction. Here it is. NO. This is AWFUL. OPT ME OUT. Pull Shark? I send potential employers and clients here sometimes, do I need to worry that they will think I am a child if I continue to use your platform? WHY ARE YOU TRYING TO FIX SOMETHING THAT WORKS? STOP. Sincerely, Me

Answers.Author: jlumbroso
Answers.Body: I do understand your concerns @blanketcat (though it's not clear if you are trolling or mean this seriously, given your profile mentions being a GPT-3 troll 😁). Like you, I have lots of experience. I have been programming since I was five, and I love code so much, I ended up teaching students how to program for a living. Having been around through the birth of the open source era, with GNU, emacs, vim, Linux, and then SourceForge, Napster, Shareaza, Gnutella, etc., ... I can tell you that GitHub has done more good globally for programming literacy and advocacy of open source than any other company on the planet. GitHub has, at scale, had a tremendous impact on programmers by helping them provide organized work. The nudges to submit a README.md, to have rules of conduct, of contribution, to have easy to use tools to submit issues, to have ever more integrated and smart workflows — all of these things help more and more people find it accessible to write usable and reusable code, and I think that bringing as many creative minds to software engineering is a good thing for the world. This gamification may feel patronizing to some, and so, it's great that it can be turned off. But it does have a positive impact, especially in the open source community where many, for several decades, were locked in silly flamewars with no real world impact. To put it another way, I think GitHub is one of those rare platforms that harnesses the value of a social platform the best. It is one of the few social media platforms that is not performative, where what matters is your work. It is a perfectly reasonable position to think that GitHub is a valuable social network, which has supported the growth of many public goods, in opposition to Snapchat, Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, that are advertising companies in disguise — that benefit from engagement at the expense of quality engagement.

Answers.Author: CarstenSavage47
Answers.Body: Your perspective is very interesting, blanketcat! I definitely understand where you're coming from. In some ways, Github feels like it's becoming more and more like Steam in a way with these achievements and all. I can't tell if that's a good or bad thing, but it's interesting.

Title: How to interpret the pull shark badge?
Author: sauntimo
Body: Love the new achievement badges, and think they are a really good idea. But, I was confused by this: According to the screenshot I have earned this badge 3 times, does that mean 3 pull requests that have been merged? However, it says "inaccessible" next to 2nd pull request merged - is that a bug? or does it think I haven't had a second pull request merged? In the last 6 years I've had several hundred merged for various companies I've worked for so does it only count merged PRs in public repositories? It doesn't say that. What does bronze and silver mean? were they both unlocked on 28th Nov 2018? How does the "x3" relate to the "bronze and silver" or the "2nd, 16th, 128th" it mentions variously? I don't really understand how to interpret any of this, and whilst I might just be being a bit slow today, I've used github for years so it makes me think new users might also be confused.

Answers.Author: DavidYang2149
Answers.Body: Hi~! Pull Shark seem to be check your PR record and show Level (not your PR count status) x1 - over 2 PR x2 - over 16 PR x3 - over 128 PR x4 - over 1024 PR Also "inaccessible" seem to be private PR. I agree new users might be confused.

Replies.Author: johnedquinn
Replies.Body: I was going to ask the same thing. I agree. Not communicated effectively. IMO it should be L1 to denote Level 1. L1, L2, L3, and so on. And when you click on the bage, it should show all 4 levels and where the user is at. Especially should show how many PRs they've merged overall (to see how close they are to the next level).

Replies.Author: odil-io
Replies.Body: Depends on how you look at it I guess, I mean, I could say that I've earned that badge 3 times instead with 3 merged PR's. I do get the confusion tho as I was confused the first few times too. But one day it just clicked with "I earned this X, Y times". But I'd rather see a different badge than how many times I've earned a particular one.

Replies.Author: vhirtham
Replies.Body: I agree with @sauntimo and @johnedquinn that the current presentation of this badge is somewhat unintuitive and easy to misunderstand. I made some suggestions in this related discussion that might help avoiding further confusion.

Replies.Author: softcode589
Replies.Body: so does that mean because if that's what they mean, they really haven't communicated that effectively. I have earnt before (check my profile), and it is actually the case. "inaccessible" means "private repository".

Replies.Author: gustavofreze
Replies.Body: I was going to ask the same thing. I agree. Not communicated effectively. IMO it should be L1 to denote Level 1. L1, L2, L3, and so on. And when you click on the bage, it should show all 4 levels and where the user is at. Especially should show how many PRs they've merged overall (to see how close they are to the next level). I agree that there should be this feature of showing progress. It's not the ideal way, but you can track where you are by looking at your closed pulls.

Title: I want Galaxy Brain badges, but how can I complete 2 Accepted Answers?
Author: fynntang
Body: I want Galaxy Brain badges, but how can I complete 2 Accepted Answers?

Answers.Author: thomscoder
Answers.Body: By answering other people questions in discussions and having them accepting your answers :) You need 2 to earn the badge. More on: https://nine-five.ghost.io/github-achievements/ Repo: https://github.com/Schweinepriester/github-profile-achievements Official blog: https://github.blog/2022-06-09-introducing-achievements-recognizing-the-many-stages-of-a-developers-coding-journey/

Answers.Author: melvincwng
Answers.Body: @fynntang, to get the Galaxy Brain achievement badge, you need to fulfill the following criteria:  Discussions should be in a public repository Get marked as answers to 2 or more questions The questions cannot be asked by you. In short, you cannot answer your own questions, those do not count. In fact, answering your own questions could prevent the achievement from displaying in your profile page. My advice here is to perhaps scour a few discussion forums, and answer a few questions based on your own knowledge/expertise. Perhaps if someone finds your answer helpful, he/she would mark your answer and thus help you to unlock the badge.  Hope these steps help you in achieving your badge! Good luck :)

Title: Arctic Code Vault lost badge when I deleted my account & changed my username
Author: barryanders
Body: Hi, I lost the arctic code vault badge when I changed my username. More specifically, I actually deleted my account after moving my repositories to a new account. I did it somewhat hastily and I didn't consider the fact that all of my past commits to other's repositories (not many but some) would no longer be associated with my account. I believe the commit(s) that got me the badge was in contribution to @mathiasbynens dotfiles . The deleted account was BarryMode . Is there any way to recover the badge? Edit: here is the pull request I remember for this: mathiasbynens/dotfiles#886

Answers.Author: rodukov
Answers.Body: I think this achievement was given to a specific usernames. Not to their accounts. I see two solutions:  Return the username to its original format; Write to support.

Replies.Author: tobiasvl
Replies.Body: I doubt it was given to specific usernames, it's probably because OP deleted their account rather than rename it. And that's not fixable.

Replies.Author: rodukov
Replies.Body: I doubt it was given to specific usernames, it's probably because OP deleted their account rather than rename it. And that's not fixable. Yes you are right.

Replies.Author: barryanders
Replies.Body: I think this achievement was given to a specific usernames. Not to their accounts. I see two solutions: Return the username to its original format; Write to support. Hey, thanks for your help. Support looks like they're going to work it out!

Answers.Author: tobiasvl
Answers.Body: You didn't change your username, you deleted your account. GitHub can't restore your deleted account. Git commits are tied to e-mail addresses, not GitHub usernames. Is the e-mail address you used for the commit in the PR associated with your new username? If not, you should add it to your new account as an alternate e-mail address, that should tie the commit to you and perhaps grant you the achievement badge again: https://docs.github.com/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-managing-your-personal-account-on-github/managing-email-preferences/adding-an-email-address-to-your-github-account However, the badge was granted at a specific time, and might not be earnable after the fact. You could contact GitHub support and explain the situation though.

Replies.Author: linuxlawson
Replies.Body: I concur.

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: the badge is linked to the email when you achieved that, as long as it is not yet taken or in your case deleted, try adding it even unverified, the problem is when you don't know that email linked to that badge but I'm not very sure when you delete your account whether it will free the email

Replies.Author: barryanders
Replies.Body: Unfortunately, I can't add the email because I think I used the noreply email associated with the account I deleted, lol. Looks like I put myself in an impossible situation here. Edit: I was able to add the original GPG key back to my account. The email isn't verified, but at least that's some kind of progress. I found the GPG key in a backup.

Replies.Author: barryanders
Replies.Body: As it turns out, I was wrong. Support found that it was a different email of mine that I still have access to... they made it sound like if I can verify the email that they will fix it! So I verified it.

Answers.Author: ryudongjae
Answers.Body: Below is a compiled knowledge of what I know, after hours of scouring through discussion forums, and trying to understand how the mechanics work (for some of the achievements at least). YOLO - Merge a PR directly without review (can add a friend as a reviewer). Repo should be public. Pull Shark - Merge at least 2 PRs into a public repo. Galaxy Brain: Answer at least 2 discussions. Take note, you CANNOT mark your own answers to your own questions. They have to be marked by another user. Discussions should be in a public repository. Also if you mark answers to your own questions, there could be a bug whereby the achievement won't show despite having >=2 answers marked by other users. Reference: I've answered 2 discussions but they don't gave me the Galaxy Brain badge. https://github.com/orgs/github-community/discussions/18454 Also, please provide a couple of hours (or maybe up to a day) for your new achievements to show. If they haven't shown by then, perhaps you did not hit some "hidden" criteria. In most cases, developers seem to get their achievements instantly though. Contact 'Github Support' if you face any issues. The community can feel free to chime in, and provide their own observations on how the requirements of the new achievements, in case I may have missed some stuff out. Hope this answer has helped you, and all the best in getting the achievement! :)

Replies.Author: shahzod222
Replies.Body: Thank you for your suggestion! I've already earned Galaxy Brain badge. I hope you will get that badge too.

Title: Feedback about new achievements
Author: DAmNRelentless
Body: Hello, I want you to give my 2 cents about the new achievements feature on GitHub. Personally, I am questioning why features like this are prioritized. I understand that in a large company like GitHub, there are a lot of people simultaneously working on different features but in my view, this feature is really unnecessary. In my opinion, GitHub tries to become a social media platform now and I really dislike that. It always was an open space where you were able to connect with other developers for awesome projects, share knowledge and experiences and help each other out. A feature like achievements just feels so competitive. It really feels like: the more you have on the profile, the better you are. People will start to compare and measure their performance through this. Another aspect that should not be neglected is that many companies also have access to an applicant's achievements through their GitHub profile. People tend to feel pressured though things like that and achievements make it even worse. I am aware that you can disable achievements on your profile but as previously mentioned this has other psychological side effects. "Why is this developer hiding their stats? Are they so bad?" Please reconsider if you really want to make GitHub the next social media platform while there are so many other feature requests that could make some use of some attention.

Replies.Body: I appreciate the response but ticking that box hides all the achievements, including the legitimate-looking ones. 😞 I would be tempted to submit a GitHub issue requesting that achievements be individually selectable in this part of the Settings... if not for most users in this Discussion being happy about these trivial achievements based on their social aspect & unwilling to look at any downside or loss of professionalism. 🤕

Replies.Author: Carlos-Simim
Replies.Body: You could make the repository private

Replies.Author: rphair
Replies.Body: @Carlos-Simim imagine (as in my case) you opened up some stupid looking PR through a fork (which cannot be made private) on a high visibility repository (which really cannot be made private) and then had to close it immediately. Under most conditions the error would recede into the background along with the closed PRs for the main repository... but not with the friendly Quickdraw icon who will always be there on your profile to say HOWDY DOODY and keep announcing that improperly posted PR to the world. Of course this is precisely what happened to me, so you can currently see exactly what I'm talking about on my own GitHub profile. Now just imagine it happening to you and whether you would want to "fix" the problem by hiding the repository itself rather than this little turd of an icon. 🤪

Replies.Author: Carlos-Simim
Replies.Body: My bad, I said you could make it private as a possible solution to your problem, I didn't check your profile. I also think they could change this, however, making one mistake public isn't a big problem in my opinion either, it happens 🤷‍♂️

Answers.Author: fredrikaverpil
Answers.Body: This is not necessarily a pointless or nonsensical achievement. Let's say you are observant of opened issues and are quick with answering (thus having either the OP or yourself closing it). But yeah, sure, one could always argue that this is a pointless achievement (or even making you look stupid). But I'm sure you can find such angles for most of the other achievements too in that case.

Replies.Author: rilysh
Replies.Body: one could always argue that this is a pointless achievement It's pointless, no matter what type of statement you want to push here. Everyone have their own opinions, instead of writing "making you look stupid" you can write your own opinion about it. This isn't anything stupid nor embarrassing to argue about it. Furthermore, I found that, this achievement doesn't make a sense just for closing a PR because in any case it didn't fit for the repository. But I'm sure you can find such angles for most of the other achievements too in that case Yeah, I did find many opinions about other achievements. If you disliked something, can't you talk about it? And here in case, I had not directly write that to remove the whole achievement structure, but did write about "pointless" ones. Such as "YOLO" (which can be different meaning for each person, as it says "you only live once"), "quickdraw" (I may close my PR for any reason or mistakenly create which may not be fit for the repo even completing in limited time) and for these reasons having such colorful icons/achievements on profile feels embarrassing.

Answers.Author: jovian-explorer
Answers.Body: It is an achievement that is given if you close a PR or an issue within 5 minutes of opening it. Although it does sound crappy, the original way it was intended to be achieved was if you close someone else's issue or PR, thereby helping them, all in 5 minutes. I know, this may seem trivial, but to be honest, it is a nice achievement to have.

Answers.Author: kycasdzxc
Answers.Body: this is just fun!🌟

Answers.Author: tzztson
Answers.Body: As the title, what is the point of this badge? I had closed one of my own PR as I mistakenly created two in one repo. However, today I noticed that I got a badge called quickdraw. But why so? I mean, I closed a PR because I mistakenly created two same PR. I didn't understand, and to be honest, it looks quite unrelated and amateurish badge. ...how this gonna help me when it's totally meaningless achievement.  ########################################################################################### ###########################################################################################

Answers.Body: Seem like when you delete some repo within 5 minutes created, you achive it

Answers.Author: luan0ap
Answers.Body: The same happened to me, I earned this badge by a mistake. Its just fun

Replies.Body: GitHub is for code hosting, you shouldn't volunteer for such a stupid thing.

Title: How do I get the Galaxy Brain badge?
Author: hello-work
Body: How do I get the Galaxy Brain badge?

Answers.Author: ShivaShirsath
Answers.Body: How to answer ? Like here

Replies.Author: airtower-luna
Replies.Body: Yes, discussions in any repository, and your answers need to be marked as solutions. You need a certain count for each level. Unfortunately there's recently a lot of spam here by people who post minimal "questions" and then select useless answers to get the achievement (like this thread). Anyone who's that desperate for the achievement should at least do it in their own repository where they don't bother others.

Answers.Author: natamartins
Answers.Body: hello

Answers.Author: PavelLaptev
Answers.Body: How do I get the Galaxy Brain badge?  @hello-work Read this thread https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/18293 it should cover all questions

Answers.Author: jdevstatic
Answers.Body: and to add, you should never mark your own answers, it will refrain you to have that badge,

Answers.Author: thenithinbalaji
Answers.Body: How do you get Galaxy brain?  Answer at least 2 discussions. Take note, you cannot mark your own answer as the answer to your own question. Answer questions asked by users in discussions and get marked. For example, if you mark this answer as "Mark as Answer", then I'll get a point for Galaxy Brain. Similarly, you will get a point when someone marks your answer as the answer in some discussion.   This badge not only has the base version, but also tiers.
